Had a lot of trouble with this game. I didn't have issues with DOS 1, where I was able to play a less than optimal party and still had fun with it. 
Everything I do is a mistake (sounds a lot like life, eh?). So many persuasion checks failed. Cannot open a single chest. Watched guides to give myself and idea, but still felt underpowered throughout the whole game, except in one or two places where I clearly fought way later than I should have had. 
Turned to the wiki for help with quests. Act 2, had a lot of quests unfinished and didn't know where to go. Some of the solutions were outside of my skill level (ie, bring this item here, cast this spell, and so on). 
I got one shotted so many times. My last fight was against aetera, she summons 2 wolves which kill one of my characters before they can act. A single spell of her removes all of my magic resistance, while I have to use several characters turns to remove hers, and something similar happened in pretty much every fight. 
I'm aware there are cheese strategies, I don't want to use them, and this includes using barrels, teleporting away, buffing in dialogue. 
So, this doesn't feel like I'm playing a game. I'm half-assing a guide, and stumbling step by step, reading a wiki then trying a bit of my own, making the wrong choice, and going back to the wiki. And reloading a lot. I think there were only 2 fights in the entire playthrough were I didn't need to reload. 
So yeah, I didn't understood this game. I have a feeling that trying to play a necro was the wrong choice for a starter character. Oh well, rant over, I'm just venting out of frustration. I wanted to like this game so much.

I love how you can basically do anything and still progress the quests in a bajillion different ways, this type of freedom isn't common in other similar games. At first I was pissed with how one of my companions had to murder an NPC for their quest which another companion needed to talk to for their own quest, but even that has workarounds too! The devs were able to make the game in a way where choices do matter while simultaneously ensuring that you don't screw up your playthrough, which again is very rare to see in other similar games.

As someone who's never touched an CRPG before nor do I have exposure to much DnD media, this definitely opened my eyes to how fun it could be. This game is immensely fun solo or with friends and multiple ways to do quests in the game, making it a very fun experience even on a replay. 

Though what makes this game stands out, is the spectacular voice acting and combat mechanics which gets you thinking how to maximize your turn, and trying out different strategies that just somehow works. Though there are certain character builds that outclass others and are easier to play while dishing out insane dps (I'm looking at you, ranger). 

Overall, a 9/10 game with my only problem is that not all of the companions in this game are written as equally well as others. I won't elaborate much due to spoilers, but I wish the next instalment to this series balances the companion writing.

I had some major issues with DoS1. But this was on sale, most of my friends liked it, and one of my friends hadn't tried it yet. I trudged through this game with them mostly because of the sunk cost and multiplayer with the friend is fun even if I don't like the game. 

I have several issues with balancing, the story, and gameplay mechanics. But a lot of those someone could argue come to taste. I personally think armor as a way to block statuses is a bandaid solution, but someone else might think that is interesting. Another example is I think the randomness is too high, but some people like rolling dice. So I'll give them the benefit of the doubt sometimes. However the UI issues I have are actually inexcusable.

When I use borderless windowed, sometimes I would click on a menu and it sends my characters off into the wilderness. Chaining and unchaining characters is finicky. Targeting is glitchy at times. The number of times enemies shot me through walls or I was blocked by an invisible something is too high. Bartering is a chore when money gets high. AI pathing leaves a lot to be desired.  

On the Balance side, I hated how much each fight depended on levels. If we weren't within 1 maybe 2 levels of the fight we would get one shot by some high initiative enemy. However, if we were at the level of the enemy, they would get vaporized. This essentially makes a somewhat open game, more or less linear, but based on the level of the enemies. The endgame was also pretty free as long as they didn't have some BS mechanic. Overall, the strategy never felt satisfying. 

I doubt I'll try another game by the devs. It just seems half baked. I honestly don't understand how people like this other than them being so starved for D&D campaigns that they don't know better.

I played through DOS2 a couple times when the Definitive Edition came out years ago and hadn't replayed it since. I finished up a playthrough recently after numerous replays of Baldur's Gate 3 and here is how it holds or doesn't hold up. Again, this review is a hybrid between, well, a review and a comparison between the two games since I am assuming people buying DOS2 now, are doing so after they played BG3 and want more Larian content, so spare me the salt if you are a DOS2 fanboy:

• The writing and the story are pretty hit or miss while the companions don't even compare to those of BG3:
-- The main story is kind of a goofy person's idea and attempt at creating a convoluted story and multiple plot points, legit "random bullsh*t go" moments around every corner, but ultimately it is engaging enough to see it through to completion. Side quests can be very entertaining so don't skip those.
-- The writing is classic Larian, with a lot of NPCs being very snarky and frankly dislikeable, with the occasional goofy but charming character thrown into the mix - reminds me a lot of Divinity II: Ego Draconis in that regard. It is a style that you have to learn to like.
-- The companions as I said don't even hold a candle to even the weakest BG3 companions - they are pretty unlikable and remain such throughout, very one-note characters that might just make you feel bad for neglecting Wyll in every playthrough.

• The soundtrack is nice if very repetitive, I can only listen to so many variations of the main theme before I have to lower the game's Music volume slider - it is an issue with BG3 as well to some extent, all stemming from the composer Boris Slavov being a rather uninspired fellow. He had big shoes to fill and a big bar to clear by succeeding Kirill Pokrovsky and frankly, I feel like he didn't even try with this game. It doesn't help that his style is more Hollywood vs. Kirill's more classical approach to music.

• The level design is one of the two aspects of this game that take first place compared to BG3. Maps are vast and can be pretty vertical, full of challenging terrain and secrets to find - BG3's is way more condensed which ultimately doesn't allow you to play much with the limited utility skills it offers (Teleport, Fly etc.).

• Speaking of utility skills, the other aspect DOS2 takes the cake on is build/ spell/ skill variety. All the available skills and spells, the fact that you can combine spells from different types together and the fantastic variety of utility spells that can interact with the world in so many ways, BG3 unfortunately just cannot compete, it gets totally outclassed.

• The balancing/ difficulty is easily the lowest point of DOS2. Even on Classic, encounters are ridiculously overtuned:
-- Initiative is a losing battle, significant enemies will always go first unless you pump Initiative like crazy, which would in turn leave you weak in every other way and still wouldn't give you the edge over many late-game bosses,
-- A very awkward Armor/ Magic Armor system that essentially adds two additional healthbars to all enemies - you have to deplete them before you are able to actually deal damage,
-- This goes hand in hand with the above but enemies and especially bosses can be ridiculously overtuned - 4+ actions per turn, thousands of HP and thousands of Armor and Magic Armor healthbars, Auras that give them a boost to stats while reducing yours,
-- Not a single battle goes by without the enemy applying "Decay" on you with seemingly any move - that status effect turns healing into a damaging effect on anyone that has it,
-- Speaking of cheese, all enemies are omnipotent. They are coded to have a level 3 of Loremaster at bare minimum so they always instantly know everything there is to know about your characters, such as their resistances/ weakness, whether they are Undead or not or if they have certain talents like Glass Cannon.

All the AI cheating starts to wear down the experience after a while, so much so that you are heavily encouraged to go for cheesy tactics like unchaining party members to sneak around after a fight has started for optimal positioning and to get in free shots, barrelmancy, terrain transmutation (lava, your best friend in Act 2) and other such stuff. The good ol' Larian encounter design philosophy of blast them before they can even move or get fucked. BG3's encounter design is far superior. While it is easier, it feels far more engaging and actually entertaining.

All in all, BG3 is the better game. If you go into DOS2 expecting more BG3, first of all check your expectations cause you'll be disappointed and second, I suggest you don't play on Classic and especially not on Tactician, unless of course you are fine with cheesing encounters, as everyone does with this game.

Still, it is worth buying and playing through in full and despite how harsh my criticism of it might seem, I'd still give it a solid 4/5.

An incredibly good game with some astounding features that will knock you off your feet. Sometimes literally. I absolutely love what Larian did with this game and that it directly led to the blockbuster success of Balders Gate. When I first played I wanted it to be more like D&D but it has it's own system and it is actually very interesting and fun. 

Got a water surface? Why not cast a lightning spell and shock everyone standing on it? Or perhaps you want to throw a fireball and turn that water into vapor and block vision in the area. Or combine the two, turn the water into vapor then shock the vapor and you get an electric cloud. Its freaking ingenious. 

Many of the spells and abilities have hidden effects, for instance if you turn someone to stone then smash  them with something heavy you will shatter them. Poison the undead and it will heal them. I thought that aspect was very cool, using poison like you use potions in most games. There are so many combinations between abilities it blows my mind that the developers made all of this function so seamlessly.

The quests and combat are excellent and the overall story is very, very cool. I wish I could tell the full story of the race me and a friend had to reach something partway through the game and how invested we both were in that reward. It was the most dramatic finish of all time, and I got swept away. We both were surprised by the outcome of that quest and that made the experience even more memorable. It is one of the best couch COOP games you can play on a console. 

If I have any gripes its that the sections of the game are compartmentalized into chapters. In repeat playthroughs, as fun as they were, involved doing the same things you did last time maybe in a few different ways but ultimately leading to the same outcome. 

Overall, this is a masterpiece second only to Balders Gate, which I strongly encourage Larian to not abandon, they built a true winner and a platform that could keep gamers entertained for generations to come.

I've started this game 5+ times and never got out of the first act.  It's a slow start. The combat also has it's own, unique flavor: focus on magic vs. physical armor, reduce armor, then rely on damage type/combination (oil/fire/ice/etc) and cc. It's pretty different from DND combat (like BG3).  I don't know, something just kept discouraging me from continuing.

But I gave it one more shot and I'm glad I did because I beat it!  It ended up being an overall enjoyable, classic rpg experience,  The combat is very challenging, and each fight does have it's own interesting mechanic.  The characters' personalities are pretty one dimensional and cliche, but I was still surprised a few times in the story.  Everyone has both good/evil qualities, so it makes for a gritty, realistic feel.  You do pick classes for your characters, but everyone kind of has the option to be good at anything.

If you're looking for something similar to BG3, it's close, but pretty different. The combat in DOS2 will feel familiar (and tbh the storylines will ALSO feel pretty dang similar) but don't expect to get attached to any of the characters the same way.

My final playthrough took 110hrs (my total gametime on Steam is 197hrs, so that's ~90hrs of redoing that first act and stopping)

Divinity: Original Sin. 

For background, I played this and the first one with members of my family, in multiplayer, in a weekly session of approximately three to four hours. It took 15 months to finish this game, 171 hours total. and I don't regret that time.  It is certainly superior to its predecessor, though I do not think that it is so improved you couldn't stand to play Divinity: Original Sin 1 afterwards. 

The addition of height and the tactical effects that allows for, as well as Blessed and Cursed variants of terrain, are the largest mechanical additions, and they do a lot. Some skills do not return from 1, and some are added, generally for the better. Mechanically, 2 is superior and siginificantly more pleasant to play. The area and town designs are superior, the side quests are generally of higher quality, and there are meaningful choices to be made - though many do not echo very far into the future. 

However, my review is here to make sure you know what you're getting into for multiplayer. Singleplayer? Like CRPGS? No problems here for you really, go play! But you can read on if you want to hear about the combat balance, story,  etc.

Multiplayer design has arguably taken a step back. The fact is that regularly telling a multiplayer group "Hey, we're going to force you to oppose eachother in various ways throughout the whole game" is... terrible. The game actually dealt social strife to my family because of how long term our investment was. I'm genuinely shocked how the ending resolves in multiplayer - Some of us didn't even get cutscenes for some major story moments at the end! 

We broke quests by talking to NPCs with the wrong characters, among a host of other minor multiplayer bugs or issues.  We got outcomes nobody wanted, sometimes due party dialogue functioning as a voting system, when we'd really rather tiebreak ourselves than because X was closest at the time and it was an even vote. 

Balancing was absolutely out of whack - we played on the middle difficulty (normal, I guess?) and it seems that even the definitive edition didn't tighten things up. Glass Cannon, Executioner, Skin Graft, and Apotheosis should probably all not be in this game, and in multiplayer made the game actively unfun (because whoever doesn't have those is just going to be less important, less effective, and less of a participant in combat, which is near if not more than half your playtime in the game. By the time you realize you need a harder difficulty to make that okay, it's not an option. Going up in difficulty REQUIRES restarting the game - which we simply weren't going to do, 100 hours and 7+ months in.) 

The designers made fun systems, but the lack of attention paid to the dynamic of multiple people interacting with all the thing they've made - story, combat, levels, gear, dialogue.... it's disappointing.

Finally, the story. I'll try to be vague but there are broad (but not specific) spoilers and criticism of the story's structure. 

The story of 2 is merely serviceable. The story of 1 was cheesy and cliche yes, but Divinity 2 is nearly well-written. It unfortunately fumbles at several key steps - 

One prewritten character/Companion should really be a forced party member given how they interact with the main plot directly continuously and are an important narrative thread to tie everything together.  

The villains have their ups and downs, but mostly ups, and at the end are poorly fitted to the narrative in their reasoning if not motivations.  We simply hadn't been given good reason to trust them, and while I can't say for sure given our ending if we should or should not have trusted them... it certainly feels like the "Good" ending is one we didn't get, and the one being hinted at at the end feels like an unreliable narrator's push to get you to do it, even though now that we're done our epilogues certainly suggest it could've been the real good ending.

Finally for story, a major supporting character is introduced as shady, assholish, and mysterious, and that lasts too long. By the time the game firmly establishes they're on your side, you've grown to dislike them. Just before then, out of the blue they try to open up to you and give you their backstory and an explanation of their mystery... but we weren't having any of that. By then, they'd missed other opportunities in the story to reveal these things, and it was just too late. Then the game goes and confirms them anyways - like what?

 Most criticism of the story here is at the root "this scene/dialogue is in the wrong place if you know what the full story is going to be" though there's only a few of these. They are all pretty big though, and so it takes a good (but not great) story down to just serviceable - even if from minute to minute, almost all the minutes are "good" and some are "great".

Still, there's not much out there for CRPG fans, and it's certainly a good game. I'd probably try and play it a much quicker pace than 15 months if I were you - it certainly didn't do the game any favors!

Divinity Original Sin 2 excels with its engaging story-line, filled with twists that keep you hooked, and its strategic turn-based combat that encourages creative thinking. The deep customization options allow for unique characters and playthroughs, enhancing replay-ability. Visually, the game is stunning, with beautifully crafted environments and detailed character models, all complemented by a fitting soundtrack. The multiplayer mode adds another layer of fun, especially with the Game Master mode for custom campaigns.

However, the game does have a steep learning curve, which can be challenging for newcomers. Some players might find the turn-based combat slow-paced, particularly during longer battles. Inventory management can become cumbersome due to the large number of items and equipment. Additionally, the game has its share of bugs and glitches, though these are often patched by the developers. Lastly, while the voice acting is generally good, some performances can be hit or miss.

Overall, the game offers a deeply rewarding experience for those who enjoy rich storytelling and strategic game play, despite a few minor drawbacks.

This game is amazing. If you are looking for something similar to Baldur's Gate 3, this is it. They use the same system, but the story and characters are different. The biggest differences are that this game forces you to take an origin character so there is no option to create your own, and there are no dice rolls but instead skill checks rely on ability points that you assign upon leveling up. Everything else is basically identical.

I think it is notably more difficult than BG3. I chose to play on "classical" difficulty, which I assume was normal as it was neither as epic or chill sounding as the other options, but quickly found out that this game really expects you to explore as much as possible and find and do all of the quests and adventures it sets out for you. If you don't, you will be severely under leveled and certain fights will be impossible. I think BG3 was a lot more lenient here. Or maybe I'm just bad. I also think that a lot of the quests are not very intuitive. I recall there was one instance where I was stuck because I never noticed there was a very small key on the floor, covered by debris, that was necessary to take to further the game. You will have to look online at some points, since completing quests for experience is so crucial. Maybe accessibility is the reason why BG3 became so popular while this never did.

However I really like the writing in this game. From the dialogue to the quirky side quests involving solving the mysteries like the lost weapons of the king Braccus Rex, it's all very fun and lays out a world that is very lively and full of wit; just like you would want from a dungeons and dragons adventure. The characters that join your party are funny and interesting and grow on you after a time so that you don't want to replace them.

This game is an investment! I'm 25 hours through and just finished act 1. But if you liked BG3 then you presumably know what you are getting into. Buy it!

My introduction to Larian Studios, Divinity Original Sin II is a story rich game that is definitely worth the price and more. The origin characters' intros (save perhaps one or two, you'll know them when you hear them) might come off exceptionally dry, but getting a full party of 4 with them means they'll have personal stories in every major area of the game. For immersion, I recommend starting as one of the origin characters to really feel like you are part of the world (rather than an insert with a random history).

Trial and error is greatly encouraged in this game: respeccing (at least your party members) is pretty straightforward, especially going into Act II and beyond, and the game usually autosaves before a potential fight encounter (often serving as a "pay attention!" cue). Many puzzles are very difficult to solve first try, with most having at least some in-game clues as to how to resolve them. The combat system will take some getting used to, especially when it comes to party composition. It's not as straightforward as "bonker", "magic bonker", "range", and "magic range", as there is a plethora of magic Area of Effect (AoE) skills that can friendly fire and/or turn the environment into a disadvantageous one for both friend sand foe. 

All in, would highly recommend. Just be aware, while the Switch versoin is very playable (and was my first platform for playing it ), the loading and saving times are significantly higher on the Nintendo Switch version, and you cannot earn Steam achivements while playing on the Switch as far as I'm aware.

I love Baldur's, and played this game a decent amount too before Baldur's Gate 3 came out... Don't get me wrong, I think Larian is a great company, so don't shoot me for this take. I think this game is intricate and has lots of cool story building and character designs. I think my main issue is completely fixable with mods, but....

I can simply not get over the decision to separate the health bars into 3 sections. Base health/Physical Armor/Magic Armor. 
If it was just resistances to dmg types that would be one thing. But without mods, say you are running a hybrid team of magic users and physical attackers you would effectively be attacking 2 separate health bars on the same enemy unit. Say I deal 50 physical damage, next turn I would need to attack a completely separate health bar as a mage before I could deal any real damage to the target. In my opinion it completely discourages hybrid playstyles and pigeon holds you into specific build types. 

If you are going to play this game, get a mod that combines health bars. Otherwise, just play Baldur's Gate 3.

A great fantacy RPG game that worth playing!
I was searching for something along the lines of PoE (pillars of eternity) , Pathfinder and similar games and I have found this.

What I liked (Pros): 
- In both terms of plot and replay-ability I have to say it was satisfying (personaly it would be better if  character desicions to have some additional effects in the game world)
- The first gameplay is apporx 25-30 hours (explore everything and do all side quests) , the replay will be far shorter.
- Great scenery and music
- Multiple characters and even animals which you can interact with.
- A vast arsenal of weapons ,spells and abilities that can be performed.

What I didnt like (Cons):
- In some parts the dialogues or actions are not match with your actions
- Some quest items can be used/lost and this will only result in having unfinished side quests.
- Once you leave the main map/location (they are 4) you cannot return 
- Ending felt unsatisfying 

Note : Avoid building your own avatar  as you will not see some of the story and some dialogue & achievement options will be not available until you assign the specific character to your party. 

Bottom line , as this was made from the same studio as Baldurs gate I was not dissapointed.
Its a great game that you can enjoy and I do recomend it (A DLC to continue the story would be neat!)

Baldur's Gate 3 reintroduced me to turn based RPG's / CRPG's after decades away and ignited a new love for these games. I wondered after BG3 finding out Larian was done with it - "what now?"...I want a similar amazing experience. I picked up the DOS1/2 bundle and wow!!!! I absolutely love this incredible game. It's obviously older and lacks the cinematic cutscenes and camera work of BG3 but don't let that put you off. divinity Original Sin 2 is a joy to play and a real challenge, the feeling you get from destroying an unfairly difficult boss is amazing. In my opinion "classic" mode in DOS2 is harder than "Tactician" in BG3. Some of the fights are unfair and unbalanced but then you remember - the devs gave me teleport and surrounded us with lava so it's cannon that they die in 1 shot to lava and move on. I cannot wait to start DOS1 after I am done with 2 but I am having such a good time before even activating a single gift bag mod....it will be a few hundred hours more. If you are like me and considering DOS2 after Baldur's Gate 3 then go for it - I highly doubt you will regret it and if you do - it's an actual challenge to finish the game so consider it one and add it to the highly lauded games you 100 percented!! for me this game is a 9/10 only losing a point for some unfair fights and many of the NPC's just being mean for seemingly little reason.

This acclaimed role-playing experience masterfully combines deep storytelling, intricate world-building, and strategic turn-based combat. Set in the richly crafted world of Rivellon, players can create unique characters or choose from diverse origin figures, each with their own personal quests.

The engaging narrative features morally complex choices that significantly impact relationships and the game's outcome. Combat emphasizes environmental interactions and elemental combinations, encouraging players to think tactically.

Exploration is richly rewarded, with hidden secrets, engaging side quests, and detailed environments that invite interaction. The cooperative multiplayer mode enhances the experience, allowing friends to tackle challenges together.

While the game's complexity may be daunting for newcomers, it provides ample guidance to ease players in. Overall, this title sets a benchmark for the RPG genre, offering a compelling blend of narrative depth and player freedom that makes it a must-play for fans and newcomers alike.

I spent more than 100 hours playing this game and adoring it, but never venturing more than a bit past Fort Joy.  After enjoying Baldur's Gate 3 so much, I thought I would come back and finally venture forth into Rivellon and see how it was.

I wish I hadn't.

Acts 1 and 2 are phenomenal.  They aren't free of flaws or bugs, but they are few and far enough between that none stick out more than the others.  Act 3 is when things start to turn.  The Godwoken are powerful.  It seems they were more powerful than Larian knew what to do with.  Enemies begin breaking established rules in combat, doing things the player is incapable of, and using far more action points than the player will ever have access to in a single turn.  Act 4, combat wise, is an absolute joke.  Act 3's poor combat choices just compound on themselves to the point that combat became something I would dread and get through as quickly as possible.  Not because it was difficult, but because it fucking sucked.  The only good part of Act 4 was Lohse's personal quest, which I won't be spoiling here.  Act 4 did however ensure that I will NEVER play this game again.  It quite honestly ruined the entire game for me.

Story 8/10
Gameplay without combat: 5/10
Gameplay with combat: 2/10

If you're looking for a fun CRPG, I cannot recommend this one.  Larian does, however, seem to to learn a hell of a lot from every game they make.  Baldur's Gate 3 is a massive improvement on DOS2.  Despite me now somewhat hating DOS2, this does give me considerable hope for the next Larian game, and make me more than a little excited for it.  Maybe they'll even manage to make the last act in their next game not the worst portion of it like it was in their last two games.  Here's hoping.

Divinity: Original Sin 2 is a masterfully crafted role-playing game that has left an indelible mark on my gaming experience. The intricate storytelling, engaging combat mechanics, and the depth of companion characters are truly commendable.

Story and Narrative

The narrative of Divinity: Original Sin 2 is nothing short of extraordinary. The plot is rich and immersive, filled with twists and turns that kept me engaged throughout my journey. Each decision I made felt significant, influencing not only my character's fate but also the paths of my companions and the world around us.

 Combat and Builds

The combat system is highly strategic and rewarding, allowing for a plethora of tactical options. I particularly enjoyed experimenting with different builds alongside my friends, each of us exploring our unique playstyles. My personal favorite was a blood build that centered around corpse explosion, which was incredibly satisfying to execute. The ability to set up such devastating combinations added an exhilarating layer to the gameplay.

Companions and Their Stories

The companions in Divinity: Original Sin 2 are richly developed, each with their own captivating backstory and motivations. Their interactions and personal quests significantly enhanced the overall experience, making every moment spent in their company meaningful.

 Multiplayer Experience

Playing with friends was a highlight of my experience. The collaborative nature of the game fostered a dynamic atmosphere where we could strategize, share ideas, and witness how each of us envisioned our characters’ progression.

Conclusion

While my journey through Rivellon was immensely enjoyable, I found myself wishing for more content beyond level 20. The thrill of smashing more adversaries and exploring the world further was a longing that lingered long after the credits rolled. My only complaint is the desire for additional content to extend the already captivating experience.

In conclusion, Divinity: Original Sin 2 stands as a pinnacle of modern RPGs, combining stellar storytelling, complex combat, and memorable characters into an unforgettable adventure. I wholeheartedly recommend it to anyone seeking an immersive gaming experience.

Soooo to start with, what I like the most in this game is that it doesn't treat you like an idiot unlike most current AAA games tend to do. You want to solve the puzzle - you've got to work for it (or google it if you feel like you cant do it ultimately. Still, that's much better than trying to solve a children level puzzle because when you finally manage to solve them you actually feel like you've accomplished something meaningful by yourself. 
The encounters in the game actually feel hard and challenging, which I like for the most part because you can't just do a no-brain button-mash through the game. You have to think and you have to plan ahead. That being said there's also an easy mode available if that's not your cup of tea.

As for my gripes with the game, I'd say there are 3:
1, XP gains favor being a murder hobo instead of doing the missions for most NPCs. Alternatively you can min-max this by doing missions first and killing the NPC afterwards. It kinda kills the roleplay aspect since you always need more XP and there are absolutely no ways to farm it. All XP sources are 1 time gain only.
2. Skill/stat balance feels kinda off. Like, I made a great build for a Warfare skill (which gives passive boost to physical dmg) with high Strength melee attacker. When I tried to do the same with Finesse (basically dexterity stat) it was straight up worse damage-wise. Also, if you ever do a physical attacker without Warfare and instead with corresponding weapon type skill (i.e. 2-handed/dual-wielding/one-handed/ranged) then you lose out on damage because for apparently no reason whatsoever Warfare just scales better, even if the descriptions suggest that they give equal boost to dmg. There's also no Warfare equivalent for mages which significantly lowers raw magical damage. Mages however do have more AoE/hazard/status spells so it kinda evens out because of a higher utility factor.
3. When you go into an encounter you're usually all grouped up, which is kinda obvious because your entire party always follows you. That's a bad thing though because you're then immediately bombarded with all kinds of spells, hazards and AoE damage. It just sucks. Enemy group on the other hand is always properly split up, all "party" roles are on their corresponding positions - tanks and melee near your party on ground level, mages and archers in the back, usually on some kind of towers for better coverage and high ground dmg bonuses. I lost many encounters because of this setting and had to reload a save and when I finally did sneak up everybody to their best positions, surprise surprise, I won. Really makes you wonder how fighting on (quite literally) equal grounds makes a fair and fun encounter.

To combat that, after some time I discovered the funny shennanigans that is the teleport spell. And oh man did I have a blast with this bad boy. You see, what I usually did was to split up my only mage character and sneak up to the enemy party juuuust close enough for an enemy to be in range of my teleport spell. I would then TP the enemy to the rest of my party and bascially bully him in the corner until dead. Then the rest of enemies would usually finally catch up to my group and a proper fight would unfold, but at this point they were missing a member for basically free so the fight was quite easy from that point on.
Sometimes The enemy I TPed would be far enough from others that they wouldn't even notice that I abducted a guy so I could repeat the process with another enemy shortly after. Near the end of the game I discovered that 10m distance away from an enemy is pretty much enough for a character to flee the battle. This led to a strategy of a quick abduction and all party members leaving combat once the poor guy is dead. Then I'd come back to the place of the crime and do it all over again. Puff and sting, but with magic :D
Actual cherry on top was that after all this bs with teleport I killed the last boss with it. (for context: the TPed character always takes some fall damage after the teleport and, as a side note, there is an achievement to kill someone this way). 10/10 would become a godwoken again.

I have a HATE HATE - LOVE relationship with this game. I played Baldurs Gate 3 before, and world wise it really holds its own. Although it feels lower budget (lacking animations and VA.) I feel the love and passion in this game that went into building the masterpiece a few years down the line. The first 20 hours(fort joy) are absolutely amazing, making you think its a masterpiece. 

However, this game is not a masterpiece. After act 1 I seriously struggled getting through it. This game does not hold your hand. It does not even teach you the ropes, in fact it throws you in the pool as an infant and expects you to swim, it also never lets up. The combat for one(classic), was always a struggle. Never through out the story are you at parity with the enemies. They are always a few levels ahead oneshotting you. With that youd expect encouragement with smart creative gameplay? No, the pathfinding is absolutely atrocious, in ways that make you wanna pull your hair out. Wanna shoot an arrow or spell at an enemy ever? A 5 inch fence will block you when, a puddle of piss is apparently an obstacle when you are shooting STRAIGHT. With that, the level design is horrid, often boxing you in and not letting you use your abilities in any meaningful way while the AI gets advantage on almost every incline and gap through a wall. Oh and how dare I forget about the elements, there are barrels everywhere, and EVERY encounter turns into a California forest fire. You could be in the ocean and still catch on fire! Really, the game practically begs you to cheat every fight with how tedious they are. The funny thing is your supposed to be Godwoken!

Its not only the combat that is unforgiving and tedious. Much of the games stories and content devolves into a "how the hell would I know that?" while playing. I've never had to use a guide until this game, where there are multiple missions which require a hyper specific thing to advance. One requiring a painting across the map to be placed on a pedestal and there was 0 guidance by the story. I like choices, but when most of the quests turn into an OJ simpson investigation as the player searches every random text, it gets tedious.

I can tell this was made with love and passion and thats what counts... but I suppose playing BGS3 beforehand left a harsh taste in my mouth which is not fair to the game completely. Thats the thing, BGS3 fixed every problem I mentioned above, so ive played and seen better. Seriously if not for the aggravating combat, its up there for the first act. I encourage you to play Baldurs Gate over this.

Overhyped game. Most gamers didn’t even bother to finish it. Out of 80% who started the game, only 10% completed it.

I admit most problems were my own, but only because the game miscommunicated with me. It is my first ever game from Larian. I was leveling up my characters correctly, but my composition was wrong. I had an Inquisitor, Rogue, Crossbow guy, and Enhancer—three physical and one magic damage dealers. And I did not have a good time. Because of the shield system, the Enhancer was useless. Enemies are really tanky, and she couldn’t destroy magic armor quickly enough to use spells. You really need to specialize in one type of damage or divide your group into 2 physical and 2 magic damage dealers. At first, it wasn’t a big deal, but the more I advanced in the story, the more problematic it became. I spent 15 hours understanding that. I think I am close to finishing the first act and escaping from the island, but who knows? The game is lengthy. And now I’m irritated. On the one hand, I want to restart the game with the correct company or push through the first act and respec my heroes later, but I will have to learn new skills again. It bothers me that you have to know this in advance or read some guides, or maybe I’m just dumb. Or all of it.

Obviously, the game isn’t awful; I wouldn’t spend so much time on it otherwise. The world is beautiful, every line of dialogue is professionally voiced, and there are so many possibilities and attention to detail. There is some inconvenience with the interface. I think it was caused by co-op. The inventory is shared, which is nice, but you still have to juggle items around. You see, only one character will receive a discount from the trader, not the whole group. You completed a quest, now the trader likes you more, but only one hero, not the rest. And now your main character got some discount, but your other guy has the barter skill, and you can’t transfer items between your characters in the trading menu. You have to close the menu, say goodbye to the trader, open the inventory, transfer all your crap to the barter guy, switch to the barter guy, say hello to the trader, and now you can finally sell with better prices. Why? It’s so annoying. For example, I could examine every creature or item within the group if some of them have the loremaster skill.

UPD
Ok, I restarted the game with pretty much the same team composition, but knowing the combat mechanics, I did a better job with skills and have now finished Act I.

Amazing game! The story so far is also intriguing. On my first attempt, I missed some quests and lore dialogue options. The game is even richer and more detailed than I thought. I’m even more impressed now. And people say BG3 is better—I can’t even imagine.

With the release of patch 7 for Baldur's Gate 3, it has come to my attention that this game isn't being glazed enough. I'm here to correct this.
I'll preface all the further rambling with a statement: I definitely recommend you to play this game. If you enjoyed Baldur's Gate 3, you'll find a lot to enjoy here as well. This games also checks all the boxes of an ACTUAL good game, such as(in no particular order):
-Good story
-Good gameplay design
-Good soundtrack
-Pretty visuals and artstyle
-And last, but not least: Freedom to play however you want, fuck up, suffer the consequences and come back for a guide.
The only real gripe that comes to mind(at least for newer players) is how the leveling and xp gain is structured, so doing exploration and side quests is not encouraged, it's MANDATORY. I'm not saying that side content isn't enjoyable, I'm just warning any potential new players that you have to scour the map, or take all the fights underleveled, which isn't ideal for you as a beginner.
Few words about gameplay:
Outside of combat its pretty much the same as Baldur's Gate 3 and other games in the genre. I recommend having a few mobility skills for both combat and exploration, since you can't really jump on your own, and you'll need to jump a lot.
In combat, just like in certain other "based character RPG" you're encoraged to abuse elemental reactions to do big damage and CC your enemies, once you break your enemies magic armor, remember that cryo is always far more effective in the rain, so if it isn't raining, cast the rain yourself. On serious note though, while there are no hard classes, you're heavily encouraged to pick a niche for every character(or even entire party) and give everyone some CC abilities or spell combinations, like mentioned above.
Just like Baldur's Gate 3, the game has 6 origin characters to serve as your companions, or if you wish, your PC. And fairly early on, you have to lock in 3 companions of your choice and the others will be discarded. So here is list with small spoiler-free descriptions to hopefully help you make this choice:
1. Fane - possibly the most lore heavy companion in the game, with the ability to unlock some "unorthodox" endings, his presence in your party is a must, as far as I'm concerned.
2. Red Prince - has a lot of story content to him and overall very entertaining character to have in your party.
3. Lohse - main star of some important side quests and her story about fightin her "inner demons" is fairly interesting. She is potential romance option, as well.
4. The Beast, Ifan and Sebille. I put them together because, while they have some cool lore about themselves and background factions of the world, their story involvment is minimal beyond them commenting on the events and having some fairly inconsequential interactins with some npcs. And I guess Ifan is romanceable too.
So to finalize this section, if you're planning on only 1 playthrough, I recommend grabbing top 3 and picking one of the bottom 3 as your PC.
Also this game has crafting. It can be inconcequential. It can be broken. You can play the whole game without interacting with it. You may find some recipes in the wild. You can find some recipes by experimenting. [spoiler] But if you really want to make use of it, just google the crafting page on the games wiki and take the recipes from there [/spoiler]
This game has its shortcomings, but once you really get into it, you probably won't notice many untill you're finished with it, so go play it

Don't let my playtime fool you, I've played closer to 200 hours of this game between profiles. It's incredible. Charming, witty writing, and lovable unique companions. The turn based combat and leveling system is crunchy and satisfying, with endless party dynamics and strategies possible, which can be reworked anytime. Presents interesting moral choices, without losing its sense of fun or the heroism you would expect in this genre. Don't get me started on the music. Inventory is a pain. And you can't raise or lower the difficulty mid game. Endgame balance is a bit weird, and some areas don't make sense depending on with companions you chose; I'd recommend glancing at walk-throughs past Reaper's Coast (2nd Act) to cut the fluff (unless you are levelmaxing). Overall, I can't say enough. My favorite CRPG, hands down.

You can find items and skill where you will hit something 100%, when you are an Apex predator later in the game you aren't at the mercy of dice rolls missing, or hitting for some tiny damage when the range is large.

Outstanding, excellent, superb, remarkable game just before perfection. I mean Baldur's Gate 3.

Divinity: Original Sin 2 stands as a pinnacle of modern CRPGs, offering a rich, immersive experience that pushes the boundaries of player choice and narrative depth. Larian Studios has crafted a world that's both vast and intricate, inviting players to lose themselves in its beautifully realized landscapes and complex storylines.

The game's greatest strength lies in its commitment to player agency. From the robust character creation system to the myriad ways quests can be approached and resolved, Original Sin 2 consistently empowers players to shape their own adventure. The turn-based combat system is a masterclass in tactical depth, rewarding creativity and strategic thinking in equal measure.

Visually, the game is stunning, with detailed environments that range from lush forests to foreboding dungeons. The attention to detail extends to character designs and spell effects, creating a feast for the eyes at every turn.

The writing deserves special praise, with well-developed characters, engaging dialogue, and a main plot that weaves personal stories with world-shaking events. The voice acting brings these characters to life, adding depth and personality to even minor NPCs.

However, the game is not without its flaws. One contentious aspect is the "true protagonist" concept, where one character is designated as the central figure of the main storyline. While this approach allows for a more focused narrative, it can feel restrictive for players who prefer a truly open-ended role-playing experience where any character could be the hero of the story.

Additionally, the recurring "shipwreck opening" scenario, while a staple of the series, may feel somewhat tired to returning players or those familiar with RPG tropes. This cookie-cutter beginning can detract from the otherwise innovative and varied nature of the game.

Despite these minor gripes, Divinity: Original Sin 2 excels in almost every other aspect. The multiplayer mode is seamlessly integrated, allowing for cooperative play that enhances rather than detracts from the narrative experience. The game's systems interlock in fascinating ways, encouraging experimentation and rewarding curiosity.

The soundtrack, composed by Borislav Slavov, deserves special mention. It's an emotive, adaptive score that enhances the game's atmosphere and emotional impact.

In conclusion, Divinity: Original Sin 2 is a landmark achievement in the CRPG genre. While the "true protagonist" concept and the repetitive opening scenario may not appeal to all players, they are minor blemishes on an otherwise exceptional game. Its deep systems, engaging combat, rich storytelling, and commitment to player choice make it a must-play for any fan of role-playing games. Larian Studios has set a new standard for what CRPGs can achieve, crafting a world that begs to be explored, characters that demand to be known, and stories that will linger long after the credits roll.

[h3]Lost in the Loot[/h3]
[i]Divinity: Original Sin 2[/i] talks a big game about epic adventures and wild storytelling, but for me? It turned into a 100-hour grind of just organizing my crap. I wasn’t battling dragons, I was battling my own OCD. They hand you the keys to a magical world, but surprise—your main quest is rearranging your damn inventory like some kind of fantasy janitor.

If you're the type who loves getting lost in every little detail and could spend hours making sure your loot’s lined up just right, knock yourself out. But if you're like me and would rather be out adventuring instead of alphabetizing your magic junk drawer, maybe give this one a pass. It’s a masterpiece for anyone who gets off on micromanaging, but for the rest of us, it’s like trying to enjoy a five-star dinner while compulsively rearranging your silverware.

A Masterpiece Beyond My Wildest Expectations

After sinking over 500 hours into Baldur’s Gate 3, I thought I needed a break—something different, but still with that Larian magic. I decided to try Divinity: Original Sin 2, mostly to support the studio, never expecting to find myself falling head over heels in love with it even more than BG3. But here I am, completely smitten!

The story is nothing short of incredible. It's clear that Larian Studios truly flexed their creative muscles here, delivering a narrative that's rich, engaging, and full of twists that left me in awe. Each companion's story is so intricately woven and deeply thought out, making it impossible not to get emotionally invested in every character's journey.

And the mechanics? Divinity: Original Sin 2 takes what’s great about BG3 and adds even more layers. The crafting system is a blast, adding a whole new dimension of strategy and customization. Plus, the freedom to explore and experiment is something I didn’t realize I needed until I had it.

But let's talk romance—wow. I thought BG3 had some steamy scenes, but Ifan in Divinity: Original Sin 2? He had me straight-up blushing! The romance is written with such passion and depth, making those moments feel intimate and real. I adore this game and the heart that was clearly poured into every aspect of it.

If you loved Baldur’s Gate 3, do yourself a favor and play Divinity: Original Sin 2. You might end up like me, falling even harder for this gem of a game. Larian has outdone themselves, and I couldn’t be happier to have discovered this masterpiece.

Somehow this game feels more like a prequel than a sequel to the original Divinity game. Combat is severely dumb downed to the point where you wonder whether the developers took the time to evaluate the strengths and weaknesses of the the combat in the previous title rather than saying screw it and strip the game of what it great in the first place and then slap a few bandaids on - 

Eg. in the first game, the player tended to simplify fights by locking down enemies with CC and whittling their HP down which led to a stale combat loops of applying CCs every turn while the enemies just stands there and stares at you. The only downside to such a strategy is that the CC abilities have a chance to miss and thus cannot be entirely relied upon. However, the developers apparently looked at that and thought to themselves- why not just implement a armor system where players would have to inflict enough damage to break that armor before they were able to apply the CCs onto the enemies? As it turns out, having armor on 99% of the enemies is a bad design choice(yes even puny little imps with no clothes on) have armor because why not) because it waters down the uniqueness and flavor of each ability in the game. You could have an potentially creative combo to approach a fight but NOPE, the spells just do the same thing as long as the enemy has their shields intact. Launching a boulder at the enemy's face has the EXACT same effect as firing an electric bolt from your fingertips thanks to this asinine armor system. Why even implement interesting synergistic spells when you handicap the player and prevent them from engaging with them? 

One might defend the new armor system by saying: just break the armor first then like the developers intended then do whatever you want to the enemies. But here lies the biggest problem- the process of stripping enemies' armor tends tear into the the actual HP bar and makes it so by the time the enemy is exposed; they are already at the brink of death so why not just invest everything purely into damage and kill the enemy before they can even react instead of figuring out synergies between different status effects. 

This leads to another glaring issue that I personally am surprised the developers have not discovered during playtest which is that the game is basically heavily incentivises the player to go all in on damage to kill off enemies before they can touch you and ignore defense because CC and status effects are impractical in this game because the enemies are able to chain CC you much more effectively that you can do the same to them due to them either overpowering you in terms of sheer numbers or simply having more action points in most fights. In fact, during my first playthrough, I had to respec my party to focus solely on damage rather than survivability for the unfair final boss battle and I ended up one shotting the boss on my first turn and skipping the second phase, which really goes to show the extent to which the game favors nuking the enemy and not playing the game any other way. Unfortunately for players who enjoy a bit of variety in their playstyles(tanks, healers, etc), this game does not seem to cater well to them at all. 

TLDR: do not be deceived by the fans who claim the second game is far superior than the first, they are likely the ones who started with the second game and could not adjust to different mechanics in the first and gave up straight away.

It's the perfect D&D simulator. I can't decide what is better: The relaxed and satisfying turn-based combat system or the gripping lore, voice acting and story that bring you in to a thrilling and unique fantasy world.

Between my first play through in 2017 and second play through now, I can safely say that it's one of the best games I have ever played, and is every bit as good as, if not better than the first Divinity: Original Sin game.

They hired better voice actors with slightly faster speech patterns that don't bore you as much as in the first game.

One thing I did not like over the first game was the addition of source points. It always bugged me how you get up to 3 slots and all of the best moves use this very finite resource. One workaround for this is to find at least 3 pyramids, put a pyramid next to a big vat of source and while venturing out put another pyramid down after combat and teleport to refill your source points.

But this is minescule. The game is 100% feature complete, like how games used to be. No DLC, no microtransactions, no expansions or any other bull crap. When you buy the game, you buy the whole game and that's it. That's how it should be.

Besides that, it's great. The combat, items, crafting, loot. Everything is balanced perfectly.

If you like Chess, you will love this. If you like Baldur's Gate, you will love this. If you have a neck beard, you will love this. If you like Skyrim, you will probably love this.

I was expecting a 40-60 hour adventure like the first Original Sin. 120 hours later, the credits roll and what a ride it's been. While a good deal more difficult and obtuse than Baldur's Gate 3, it's a steep improvement over Divinity Original Sin. The voice acting (narration included) was fantastic from start to finish, and the story, while largely your predictable high-fantasy fare, threw a couple of twists in that I didn't see coming. The characters are all very well written and interesting, especially once you start diving into their individual side quests. I loved the character development in each party member (especially The Red Prince's and Fane's), and while I typically don't revisit games once I've beaten them, I'm very much looking forward to taking another run through this excellent RPG down the road,

Edit: It's worth noting that I played through the majority of this game on my Steam Deck and it runs almost flawlessly out-of-the-box.

I wish to god i could recommend this game. The first 99% was wonderful. The combat is engaging, the world is interesting, there's great storytelling, all that.

But what's the fucking point if the big finale bugs out in a completely unpredictable and unavoidable way?

I've spent the past 3-4 months working through this game, I got to the point of no return last night, and decided to wait till this morning to have my big epic finale that I've been building to for months. 

And then it just wouldn't work. No matter what I tried, the enemies just wouldn't attack me. I kept whacking their inanimate bodies until they went unconscious, and eventually killed the correct one which triggered the end of the game. I didn't get any big cool epic fight that I've been waiting for. All the allies I made and quest lines progressed to help me in this fight were pointless. I couldn't use Anathema, Sir Lora never got to fire off his acorn spell, and the actual final boss never even spawned.

Larian, what the hell? I know what you guys are capable of. It's clearly demonstrated in this game, in DOS1, and in BG3. How, after 7 years, is such a game breaking bug still here?

I was actually planning on replaying it on an easier difficulty since I did tactician which slowed me down and made me lose interest in the story at some points due to the menial nature of some combat encounters. But now, I have no desire at all to replay this game. What if I invest another 100+ hours just to have all momentum fall off a cliff at the end???

Seriously, this is just sad. How can you deliver such an amazing game and allow all of that to be so thoroughly ruined by such a game-breaking bug? I literally feel like months were wasted.

Mixed feelings about this game.

Overall i'd say it's above average. Lacks polish in certain areas, i.e. whatever is coded for the inventory scrolling with mouse wheel feels quite buggy, scrolling slow / stuttery or deciding to go back at the start of list or randomly scrolling the opposite direction i'm trying to go, or not scrolling at all.

I preferred the combat / character building in the first Divinity OS. Graphic-wise it also had more contrast between different items and environments making it easier to spot poison and other surfaces,  along with furniture/things.

I've had and played this game since Early Access.

They attempted to make the tone more serious but couldn't stay consistent in it. 
It's like they started with the idea of a more serious/grim scenario, serious epic art style, world, soundtrack but then during development they either forgot or changed hands working on it and and started adding more silly/light hearted elements with the voice acting, origin characters and other stuff they added along the way on top of the base grim world.

Most of characters feel like they don't take seriously the world they are in, in particular your companions. You could be in a blood soaked room with cadavers everywhere the environment and sountrack give off a dangerous vibe but then the characters would crack light toned comments or talk like they are taking a picnic stroll. It is rare if anybody is ever on edge or takes the situation they are in appropriately.

Lohse almost killed an npc? Shrugs it off and avoids the topic.
Sebille steps in while you are having a conversation and murders the npc? No big deal.
Exploring and looting torture chamber with a maniac torturer across the room? Fane is over there commenting on a portrait, talking about artistic rights.
Someone tries to assassinate Red Prince for the 12th time? Oh no big deal, actually just an annoyance.

Almost every voice actor, even for animals has an accent (british? not sure) in some cases it's so heavy/forced which i find grating to the ears. I think i recognize voices from the first Divinity OS but here the accent is way more pronounced. Everytime i start a new playthrough i want to strangle Magister Siwan whenever i hear her talking.

The narrator sounds like they are from the Teletubbies show, or reading a children's fable, hearing him saying comments like "did you expect a needle?" with almost a puzzling/mocking tone while i'm checking an hay stack in a sinking ship or in a bloody dark prison was completely out of place.

The voice acting doesn't fit and with the rest of theme and art style of the game. I tried to play the game without voice sounds and it completely changes how the conversation and characters are perceived.

So does talking to animals, as almost all of them have cringe silly voices or dialogues (if you have the ability to talk to animals).

Then early in game, your character who is a prisoner survive a ship wreck literally by miracle and wake up on an island  (which was the ship's destination btw). Almost everybody from the ship has died, except some of the prisoners, so even if you guys survived you are still in a shitty situation, wearing rags, barefooted, using makeshift weapons. 

The Soundtrack and environment give off the idea that you have to survive on this island and the situation is bittersweet, but then you meet a cat who sounds stoned, they follow you without even knowing why and in the Definitive Edition they added Sir Lora whom you meet early in the game, a squirrel wearing a skull helmet and riding an cat skeleton, talking something about an invasion of giant Acorns(??) so the tone consistency goes out the window meanwhile not even a few meters ahead there are other prisoners all wearing rags and probably starving, awaiting for their sentence and some are hoping to escape the place. The game keep having this conflicting tones where you are supposely in a somewhat grim scenario but then they add in silly non serious stuff.

I didn't have this issue with the first D:OS, because the tone overall was more consistent.

But here with the more serious soundtrack and theme it's like they tried to put oil with water.

The way the armor system works in this game makes physical and magical damage have absolutely no synergy with each other.

Difference of levels compared to enemies make an huge difference, when you are still building up core talents, gear and passives/skills.

You can't hard CC enemies until you deplete their physical or magical armor. later on (but not so late) almost all enemies will start having teleportation, ranged or jump skills making defensive positioning/kiting less relevant. I.e. who had the idea of giving ranged oil boulder throwing skill to crocodiles or turtles..? Shield characters get a ranged throwing skill early on which they'll use right away meaning they'll be able to hit you from a distance on their first turn.

So when you encounter higher level enemies it's almost guaranteed you can't CC in the first turns cause of their huge armor. Encounter with enemies of higher level almost feel not possible or at huge disadvantage.

It also tends to turn into a gank/focus on target fest to finish them off quickly after you manage to CC them and ignore the rest of enemies since they still have their armor values on so you can't hard disable / CC them anyway.

In the first Divinity OS, you could deal with higher level enemies by keeping the distance, CC and use of other skills. Melee enemies would have to walk/run toward your party and archers/mages would keep their distance. If you approached the archers they'd switch their weapon to melee. Zombies would have to approach party to melee range.

It is better to have your group use either all physical or all magical type of damage / CC.

Most encounters are solved with combat, which is often forced on the player (you can't talk your way out of it). This pushes player to hunt for more experience and levels before approaching certain places as they'll have to inevitably fight.

Enemy AI in combat is too smart in some cases. Feels like i'm playing against a pvp AI, they go and focus the squishiest target and if you put reflect damage on your characters or high resist they'll just ignore them.

In the first D:OS enemies would still try to use poison on your zombie character, and wouldn't blatantly ignore your character just cause they couldn't damage them properly. There were nice things like headless zombies who would act erratic and swing the air (since they are headless and they can't see).

Experience to gain levels is limited, you'll gain from killing certain npcs, exploring areas, triggering events or certain decisions you make during quests or dialogs.

A certain course of action rewards better exp than others, and since the gains are limited throughout the game it makes it feel less rewarding to play a certain way. Some decision reward less or no exp. WIki comments are full of tricks on how to maximize / loot and exp gain for this reason.

It is also quite dangerous to approach a combat undergeared and underleveled.

There is an "ideal" order in which to do things, for example if you go to certain places you'll miss out events happening somewhere else, or some npcs may be already dead by the time you arrive, the order in which to do these things is not clear on a first playthrough. You can also potentially gain extra exp by being present during an event/cutscene or traveling to places in a specific order.

The game is not easy enough to ignore extra levels/experience, depending on how you approach combat. Unless you want to cheese encounters with ambush or or other tactics combos which i'm not gonna mention here.

The limited experience gain affecting gameplay decisions (and ruining roleplaying) along with the bad armor system are what bothered me the most and prompted to write an early review.

May update it if i complete the whole game.

I've played Divinity RPGs since the original Divine Divinity over 20 years ago. The series has always had personality and worlds just jam packed with interesting encounters, then Original Sin 1 experimented with turn-based combat and co-op. They used a vibrant elemental system where you can, for example, create a rain cloud to drench an area, then use lightning to stun anyone inside the puddles. This made it too easy to stun-lock enemies (or for them to stun-lock you) for a really long time, so the sequel adds armour which must be whittled down before somebody can be crowd controlled. They also smoothed all the bugs out of co-op, allowed 4 players, and even encouraged players to compete with each other and see each other as rivals. 

Original Sin 2 is the culmination of everything Larian has learnt in over 20 years of making RPGs. Personally, I prefer it to Baldur's Gate 3 as it isn't limited to the annoying D&D combat system, and all the characters aren't over the top and horny. My only potential criticism is that, as with all modern Larian games, the first act of the game is of the utmost quality because it is playtested so much but then you start to notice a slow drop in quality the further you go in. Not that later parts are bad per se, they just don't have the magic that the early areas do.

Divinity Original Sin 2 stands tall as one of the greatest RPGS ever made, this game deserves more recognition and credit. The world and setting(s) they have created in this game are truly fascinating and are incredibly diverse. The locations remind me of a fantasy game, however it has its own unique twist and flair to it.

The characters in this game, especially the companions are incredibly well written and very worth your time learning and understanding. Each companion has a different reaction to the actions you commit in this world and they all have their own usefulness and negatives in combat. It is not so simple as "a mage can heal but not do other mechanics". You have full control over how to spec your companions and character, I made a necromancer knight and it was incredibly viable throughout the whole game and never felt pressured by the game to doing something else. 

The story in D:OS2 might be my most least favourite aspect, it starts of very strong and engaging, and peaks at act 2 with branching story lines and engaging content and characters that make you keep playing late into the night wondering what is going to happen. However, during the later acts of the game, the story definitely starts to weaken a fair bit, the plot becomes confusing and wrongly paced and it becomes a point where you say to yourself "I just want to get this done with now". The constant puzzles and drawn out battles in act 3 just to drag out the playtime were not helped by the constant backtracking for certain items that game had not clear were necessary to progress the story. However, the combat and exploration is still incredibly rewarding and fun, so it evens out. If you are one to get burned out quickly, this game will not be for you at all.

Overrall, D:OS2 stands tall as a great game which has an incredible amount of quality content, paired with well-written characters and an interesting map. However, certain hindrances such as the fall off of the story, and the weirdly paced later acts and drawn out puzzles and battles must be noted.

What an incredible turn based RPG. I've spent just less than one thousand hours on this masterpiece which means its my most played Singleplayer game in my adult life (admittedly some hours were playing multiplayer with friends but still). Now there's no way that I'm going to be able to list all the good things about this game in one review, but I'll try my best and highlight some really good aspects to hopefully encourage anyone reading this to give it a go. 

Pros -
Firstly, the music in this game is AMAZING. It either sounds completely badass for fights or incomparably elegant for exploring the world. There were so many times during my many playthroughs that I had to make the decision of either humming along to the music or letting my ears fully embrace those beautiful instruments. 

Visually this game is stunning, the details in the world and the particle effects of abilities/spells look so well done and make it feel so satisfying when you cast them. I also really appreciate that this games movement is very freeing for a turn based RPG. I've always disliked those games where movement is restricted to like a chess board with squares. Having your characters quite literally being able to move anywhere feels so much better. 

Next up, the story. [b]EVERYTHING[/b] has lore in this game. If you love reading and want to read pages and pages of lore, character backgrounds and potentially hundreds of books scattered across the game, then you can most definitely do so. But its not forced onto you. Most books that you find throughout the game aren't necessary to progress, and a lot of the time there will be an option to resolve problems by fighting if you prefer a little more action. Its completely up to you how you want to play. 

Lastly, I want to talk about the character creation. The character creation in Divinity is phenomenal. Obviously you can change the look of your character to how you want but more importantly, there are 10 Skill categories that you can allocate points to. You can mix and match them together and pair them with *mostly* any type of weapon in the game. The combinations you can make are endless. For example:

Want to be a persuasive fire-wizard that uses daggers instead of the usual staff/wands?
Want to be a non-confrontational thief that escapes his enemies by turning the floor to ice causing them to slip?
Want to be an archer that fires love arrows to temporarily make his enemies fight for him?
Want to be a cleric wielding a giant axe who can explode corpses?

Well you can have all 4 in the same party! I could talk about this game for hours but at the time of writing this these are the aspects of the game that came to mind. Now I'll talk a little bit about some very minor cons that don't put the game in any bad light but I feel are good to know anyways.

Very Minor Cons - 

Gift Bags: [b]If you don't care about achievements then move onto the next con[/b] -- Gift bags are the developers way of giving their own made mods for divinity. They are free little game mechanics that you can choose whether to enable in your game or not. (I highly recommend that you [b]do not enable any of these for your first playthrough[/b] as some make the game considerably harder/easier). Some of these settings are incredibly useful but the issue is since these are acted like mods, achievements are disabled if you enable them, so you will need to replay the game without them in order to gain any. I wish the devs would have actually implemented some of these into the base game rather than adding them as mod-like settings after.

Inventory: Inventory management in this game could be a liiiiiiittle better. There's nothing necessarily wrong with the inventory system, but there are definitely a few QOL changes that they could have added. One example being the ability to name bags. Throughout the game you will pick up individual bags that you can place in your inventory and put any item inside. They are incredibly useful in tidying up your inventory and reducing clutter, but these bags cannot be named. So you will end up having to repeatedly look inside each bag to find out which bags have which items. Additionally, when crafting stuff, if an ingredient is inside one of these bags, the crafted item may appear in the bag of the ingredient instead of just appearing at the bottom of your inventory for you to sort out. Again, not exactly a game-breaking problem but definitely slightly frustrating when you have lots of items in a bag and now need to find a random crafted item amongst them all.

Other than whats listed above I just wish the game never ended honestly. I want more cool spells, more races, more talents, more fights, MORE OF EVERYTHING. Truly a really incredible game, please give it a go because the developers deserve it. 

Thanks for reading <3.
