GG but worse than BG3 for me...

So my issues with this game:

-Inventory management is trash. It was bad in Baldur's Gate 3, but at least you could select multiple items at once in that whereas you can't in this unless playing with a controller. Funny that they updated the definitive edition to work with controls and multi-item select like BG3, but I would say even better than BG3 because I like the skill bars instead of radials. I don't know why they didn't update mouse & keyboard this to have more modern QoL functions like BG3. I could play with controller, but I prefer with mouse and keyboard.

-Randomized equipment and equipment management is annoying. After one level of experience, I usually have a ton of equipment. So, then I have to go through the hassle of identifying the equipment. Why can't I just see what I have, rather than taking this extra step? After identifying the equipment, I have to see if it works for any of the characters. Sometimes the random equipment (ie lots of "mage gear" vs warrior gear) makes me completely want to respec a party member to a different "class" which means having to redo all of the stats, equipment, talents, and action bars. Even if it doesn't make me want to respec, getting new equipment often still means having to go to the respec mirror to optimally adjust my stats. You'll also need to spend time removing runes from the old equipment and adding it to the new equipment. For example, I have an Archer. It has a minor dip into a few non-ranged aspects to have more mobility abilities. If I get a new piece of gear that increases my armor by a lot, but doesn't have the points in my mobility dip I have to go respec just to get the proper points in the skills I want. This is not hard, it's just very time consuming... even if you only do it once per level. I don't think the right answer is to check every piece of gear as you get it, because often you will want to respec unless the gear randomly gives you the stats it wants. The alternative is to be lazy and not update my equipment and have a lot more difficulties in combat. The last little niggle is that when you visit vendors selling gear, the gear is randomized. So you can save-scum to try and get gear that aligns with what you want for your character. This ended up being way too time-consuming and I stopped doing it. Shields are especially weird in this game because you often need a certain level of constitution to use. If you lose constitution due to a status effect, the shield will unequip. So, you've just lost a PILE of armor and stats because of a status effect when you could have just not put points into constitution and upped your intelligence by equipping another wand. You can overshoot your constitution to try and avoid this, but either, you don't unequip other gear when you lose stats or no other stats are attacked as much as constitution, which is strange. Also, mages using shields feels a little weird thematically, but I wanted to do this so they would be a bit less squishy. Often not worth the hassle with the random unequipping.

-In some ways, I like the combat more in this than BG3. There seems to be a greater variety of combat abilities and status ailments. On the other hand, the combat is designed in such a way that you want to do as much damage as possible as quickly as possible so you can start crowd-controlling enemies. CC status effects basically don't happen unless the character has lost it's physical/magical "HP" armor bar (the type being relevant for certain effects). This leads combat to feeling pretty volatile. I also feel they leaned way too much into environmental effects. It feels like you're always walking in poison/fire/etc. Maybe I'm just too casual for this level detail in combat. The encounters feel especially swingy in the late-game (deathfog spiders, multiple trolls at once, etc). Maybe they are just encounters I should be skipping since they seem to be optional. Though, some of the story-related encounters seem pretty brutal too. Finally, there are source points & abilities. They are just points that allow you to use cool powered-up skills. The problem with this is that you can't always consistently get these points in your locale and sometimes the enemies will absorb your source points and pummel you with them. So, it makes me want to play in a fashion where I don't use these cool abilities because I don't always have access to the means of recouping these points in a non-time consuming way, the enemies can use them against you, they take up more skill slots than non-source abilities. It kinda feels like teasing you with cool things that you get punished for, when actually trying to use them. If they were just replenished after every combat rather than making you go through rigamarole to get these points back, they might feel more worth the effort.

Potential issues with the genre (in terms of my preferences): ?

-So many freaking items and objects to loot! This kind of ties into the inventory management. I don't know if this is typical of Skyrim/Witcher 3/etc. but after having played BG3 and D:OS2, there is just way too many items. I don't want to pick up every little thing and then have to wade through what to sell and what not to. Additionally, I hate selling random items when it could have potentially been used for crafting excellent items. So crafting in general is pretty blah. If you don't reorganize an item by its icon, good luck finding it. It's also very time consuming to pick up every little item and check every vase. This tends seems to be more common these days, as I thought both Octopath Traveller games had more gear than I was used to in JRPGs. CRPG's seem to have it more than JRPG's... or the JRPG's of yore, anyway. What's been your experience with this?

-A world of freedom means I'm trying to shape destiny. This is time-consuming and I don't like looking things up online. I would just prefer to play. That said, it's annoying to make choices that affect your game in a negative way. It's easier to just save-scum and choose an alternative outcome. It's not even something I always do, but some decisions I do want to change. This also inflates the play time. Playing out a sequence, not liking the result of a choice, save-scumming and replaying the sequence or a quest giving you a choice so you read up on the outcomes so you can choose what you want. Maybe I should just be going with the choices I make regardless, but I remember playing BG3 the first time with a less save-scumming methodology and 2 of my companions storylines basically became non-existent and it wasn't even immediately obvious that things would turn out this way until 10's of hours later.

-Combat save-scumming. It's annoying when you don't know a combat is coming (probably through some dialog option) and then combat surprises you and you get AOE-nuked into near oblivion because when you naturally run around with your party they stay clumped together. Sometimes you'll even try to hobble through the fight and succeed, but then when you fail, it feels like time wasted. So, then you restart the game and properly position your characters before you send someone to talk to an NPC. This particular option kind of breaks thematic immersion when you're strategically setting up your party's positions before they know they are going to get into a combat. I don't want to waste time setting up combat before I talk to any given NPC and sometimes you randomly get ambushed while walking around, so it's bound to happen.

-Forced flavor text reading. What I mean by this is that in D:OS2 and BG3, you can find a whole bunch of different books. You should read these books. These books can open new quests, complete current quests, give you hints on solving a puzzle, and let you learn new recipes. I don't really want to do this. I have basically stopped reading opened the read window and immediately shut down to try and get quest/recipe triggers.

D:OS2 was too busy developing cutesy mechanical interactions to focus on plot or character development. The story is paper thin and stereotypical, with fairly obvious and unexciting plot twists, the dialogues and voice acting are hackneyed, and the art direction adds nothing to your run-of-the-mill fantasy setting (sometimes bordering on Blizzard-level ugly), even if the maps are sometimes quite pretty. Dialogues and player decisions often feel meaningless. The UI's awkwardness left me at times struggling to resurrect a character, or find a spell or scroll (In fact, sometimes memorized spells were unexplainably absent from the menu bar). The puzzles most often rely on arbitrary idea associations made by the developers, which players need to guess or, most likely, go online to fetch the solution. The two-tier system of power for weapons and armor (quantitative—1 to 20—AND qualitative—"Common" to "Divine") is unexplainable and only leads to awkward calculations. There are other features that retract from the experience, such as the baffling level power up of villager NPCs and enemy minions, which always match the player's leveling up as we progress in the story. Overall, the game confuses arbitrary complexity with depth. A very frustrating experience.

처음에 대사도 많고 익혀야 할 시스템도 많아서(기존 드래곤에이지, 발더스 등 수 많은 RPG 게임을 했음에도 독특한 전투 방식과 스킬 때문에 공부해야 함) 바로 진입하기가 쉽지는 않았음. 좀 시간 투자하여 공부해서 익숙해지고 나면 전투 재밌게 할 수 있고, 곳곳에 숨겨진 아이템 찾아서 캐릭터 업그레이드 하는 재미 좋아하는 분들은 추천.  

엘더스크롤이나 마이트앤매직 시리즈 같은 오픈월드에 비하면 상당히 제한된 맵이지만, 그 좁은 공간 안에서 벌어지는 다양한 변수의 디테일들은 역대 최고라 생각함. 2회차까지는 공략 보면서 플레이했고, 공략없이 3회차 플레이중이지만 아직도 처음 겪어보는 요소가 있음. 발더스게이트3도 이런 디테일을 가진 라리안이 만들었기 때문에 원작보다 더 호평받았을 것이라고 봄. 

단, 전투가 익숙해지면 최고 난이도로 하더라도 막강한 상태이상을 특정조건에서는 적에게 100% 걸 수 있고 거의 모든 퀘스트를 진행했으면 캐릭터가 강해졌을거라 전투가 초반보다 후반이 더 수월해짐. 메인 총 6명 캐릭터라서 스토리를 위해서는 4인팟과 2인팟 이렇게 2회차 플레이를 추천하고, 난이도 더 어렵게 할거면 3인팟이나 1인팟을 하면 됨.

I'm happy to play BG3 in Honor mode, but I really don't enjoy the combat of D:OS 2. I tried lowering it down from Classic to Explorer mode, which made the combat easier but not enjoyable. I looked up multiple youtube videos for pointers, but I just can't enjoy this game's combat; the whole thing about stripping an opponent's armor or magic armor and then using chain crowd control is lame as hell, and having enemies destroy you with AoE at the start of every combat if you don't manually unlink your party and reposition them is... also lame as hell. I just could not enjoy this game's combat.

What about exploration? You go to a door, try to open it. It's locked. You try to pick the lock; your rogue's skill is too low, and your precious lockpick is gone forever. So you try to break it; now your weapon's durability is shot and it's unusable in combat. You unequip your weapon, and punch and kick the door. A hundred kicks later, it's open, and you can go into a room and pick up like 2 gold, which is a tiny fraction of what it costs to buy another lockpick. Who the hell thought this was a good idea?

What about the characters, setting and story? Setting and story look interesting, but I didn't get very far, so I can't tell for sure. Some characters were alright, others I just wanted to murder for being total pieces of shit, like the Red Prince. I didn't actually like any of the origin companions though, like I did instantly like Lae'zel in BG3. D:OS 2 companions were just... okay, at best. Which is not too bad, and I'm sure they have interesting storylines down the road, but it's not good enough to keep me engaged and playing a game whose gameplay I've flatly disliked.

Clearly, many players enjoy this game, if you look at its excellent review scores... but just as many players are like me, who did not enjoy it. D:OS 2 has 97 achievements, and only 8 of them have been completed by over 50% of players. I quit halfway through exploring Fort Joy, the first town you get to right after the prologue, and got multiple achievements that only 30 or 40% of players have gotten. More than half of all players quit this game very, very early- they just don't bother to be like me, and leave a negative review on the way out. I love Larian and BG3, but I can't love D:OS 2.

If you're a casual RPG player and want to hop into the kind of RPG like Baldurs Gate then this game is the perfect example, developed by the same Larian Studios, this game is amazing. But i just wanna say for me this was probably the hardest tactical RPG i've ever played [i](if you're achieving 100% completion)[/i], beating the game in tactician mode really makes me think a lot about every action that i'm gonna do. Maybe in other games you can exploit certain fights by playing hit & run, or maybe by using the ability to sneak and one-shotting the enemy. But in here you can't really do that all the time since the game use "Action Point" in their turn based battle system, so you must be skilled and creative in every fight, especially the final fight towards the ending, good luck with that! But that doesn't mean this game doesn't have any cheese method, there's many, but you won't figure it out if you're not clever. Oh and you can't farm xp in here, enemies won't spawn after you kill them, so if you're trying to get the best possible xp income you'll have to check the guide but at the risk of spoilers.

Regardless of the difficulty, this game is fun, like really fun, there's so much freedom in the character build, story development and many more. I really liked how the game progress each arc, every decisions you make will shape the story and how other characters will act towards you later in the game. One of the best RPG so far!

The game features stunning graphics with vast areas to explore, a plethora of weapons and crafting materials, and an engaging storyline with numerous characters to meet and interact with. The battle system is fair and methodical, and the option to play with friends enhances the experience, whether locally or online.

It’s a perfect choice for home entertainment when you’ve run out of movies to watch and are looking for something to dive into. Highly recommended!

It is astonishing to me that this game is so loved even though the playthrough is rather linear and mechanics of combat is split into 3 scenarios.

Scenario 1: you get ambushed and you die
Scenario 2: you have a mage with teleport and bunch of oneshotting aoe spells and you one shot the enemy
Scenario 3: you have a warrior with full stats into strength, 2 handed and warfare and you one shot the enemy

I finished this game only in tactician mode once where the devs decide to handle the difficulty in the most boring way possible; by increasing the mobs stats into ridiculous amounts. The combats in this game are in 90% of instances an ambush which makes for a boring experience.

 gaming experience for me because I am usually the nerd in the group getting all the lore info possible)

Went back to this game for the first time after thoroughly enjoying Baldur's Gate 3.  Definitely scratches the same itch!!

I bought Divinity Original Sin 2 originally because i wanted to test the waters with turn based combat before i spent the big bucks on Baldurs Gate 3. I really came to this game/genre for the choice driven narrative fun, but i ended up enjoying the turn based combat just as much if not more. It's almost like a weird game of chess, except your pieces are cherished companions with moves that you handpick and stats that you fine tune throughout the journey. 

The Story grips you enough to hold your attention to see its conclusion, with some very surprising twists along the way. There is a narrator accompanying you throughout the game giving context to everything, i actually almost preferred this over cut-scenes, it was just really charming. Not to mention the writing... Larian Needs to give their writers a big raise, every single conversation and narration is just so beautifully written.

 Many decisions felt like they held a lot of weight, and sometimes would leave me starring at the screen in disbelief at how they would alter the course of my game, or characters fates etc. One thing that really blew me away was when my pal Mr SpoilerMaybe died, it wasn't scripted it just happened. I was overcome with rage against the Magisters and vowed to murder them all after that. 

A big issue i had with the game though was sometimes in the logbook it would recap things (as it does) but it wouldn't account for a decision i had made and the information would be inaccurate. Something like "Billy killed Joe and you ran" when in reality i killed Joe one mission ago. Or sometimes you talk to someone and they act like you have spoken to them before. This happened to me when i first arrived at Fort Joy at the start of the game. There are so many ways to complete the first quest that the paths start to overlap and get tangled and you end up talking to somebody about a plan you both conjured up in a previous conversation that never took place. These issues were few are far between however.

Issues aside this game is great, from the soundtrack, writing, atmosphere, combat, choices, EVERYTHING IS GREAT. I very much enjoyed every aspect of this game, and if not for the issue i mentioned above and a really over complicated puzzle towards the end of the game, i would call it a masterpiece. 

8/10

Divinity: Original Sin 2 - The Ultimate Fantasy Soap Opera

One of the best RPGs there is. 9 / 10

If you've ever wondered what it would be like to team up with most eccentric friends to save the world, then Divinity: Original Sin 2 is the game for you. From the moment you crash-land on a prison island, you're thrown into a whirlwind of drama, magic, and questionable choices.

First off, character creation is like being a kid in a candy store. Want to be an undead lizard person that likes the dead more than the living, become a necromancer. Want to summon a beast that does everything in your place? Go for it. A dwarf polymorph? Sure, why not. The combinations are endless, and each is more absurd than the last. I spent more time on character creation than I did on actual gameplay in some other RPGs. I went through Fort Joy 3 times, cause other builds seemed more fun, until i figured out you can respec later on the ship. 

The combat system is like a game of chess, where every piece is on fire, and the board is soaked in acid. It’s turn-based, which means you’ll have plenty of time to plan your next ridiculous move. Get a barrel from your inventory, misclick, and see your party go down in flames. Rethink your choices, reload and do the same stupid shit you did before. Make a devious plan with your friend, teleport them near the enemy and see them get electrocuted in static mist...oops...

But once your combo goes they way you planned, you will feel like a GOD that can do no wrong.

Speaking of friends, the multiplayer mode is where the game truly shines. Nothing brings people together quite like a heated argument over who gets to be the talking squirrel’s best friend or why your buddy thought it was a good idea to throw a teleportation pyramid into a pit of lava. 

The story is engaging, filled with plot twists and moral dilemmas. After every interaction with NPC, you wonder if other option was better and what cool stuff you missed. 

There are some cons. Leveling system is quite confusing, physical armor and magic armor is quite the disappointment from DOS1. Knockdown is the most important thing to do, everything else is secondary.

*shudder* The oil field fight.. *shudder*

In conclusion, Divinity: Original Sin 2 is a wild ride of hilarity, strategy, and pure fantasy joy. Whether you’re summoning an army of totems, bartering with a crab, or just trying to figure out why your inventory is full of tainted fish, this game delivers on all fronts. Just remember, no matter how epic the quest, never trust a friend.

I tried to like this game, but I'd barely gotten to Fort Joy (the first area of the game) before it became tedious.

I'll start by saying the game has some strengths. The entire game is voice acted, which is nice. There're lots of NPCs to interact with, lots of quests to do, a class system complex enough for builders to work through. There is quite a bit of scope to plan your characters, and the option to play multiplayer is also nice (it is unique as well in all the RPGs I've played). It is highly nonlinear, and there are many ways to meet a quest objective. You can also kill (almost) any NPC, which completionists might find fun just to see how the plot reacts.

However, the game is also plagued with problems:

- The plot is very dry. I more or less lost track of it completely soon after arriving at Fort Joy. The game doesn't introduce what Source is, why Sourcerers are considered dangerous, what Fort Joy is, and so on (I actually learned this stuff from Wikipedia).
- The characters are very dry. I came to know my party members OK, but almost everyone else just fades out of memory. For example in the first zone there's a blue dragon, but what their name is I don't remember, or why they were shackled when I first met them. They're completely colorless and leave no impression, and I barely interacted with them.
- You do a lot of running around, but there's no fast travel beyond waypoints. After you've waypointed you still have to s-l-o-w-l-y walk to wherever you wanted to go (even worse if you split your party).
- Inventory management is tedious. It's not immediately obvious which items are junk, which are equipment, or even which are armor pieces and which are weapons. There's no way to search for which items add to a particular stat. Furthermore the items have weight, so you can't lug everything around, and there's no way to search for the heaviest items so you can drop them.
- Combat is also tedious. Even if you're level 8 and your opponents are level 2 - which means you kill them in 1 hit - you still have to go through the same turn-based combat, watching their animations.
- You also repeat the same tactics against most opponents, adding to the tedium.
- Even worse, combat is needlessly complex. I've lost count of the number of times I've friendly fired. Friendly fire in this game is not like casting a Fireball and having the edges of it hit my teammates, it's things like aiming the Fireball at an enemy and then having it hit my teammate because they were in the line of sight - there is no warning that this will happen. Similarly, I've stunned myself by casting lightning spells on something who's standing in a pool of water. I still haven't figured out if this always happens or if it's a percentage-based chance. Not having "combat preview" is an incredible drawback.
- There's no difficulty scaling. This means the game is less nonlinear than one might think, because you might not have the levels to do stuff in a different order.
- There's also a limited amount of enemies, which I suppose means there's no grind, but also means that, combined with the above, you should kill all the nonessential NPCs you can for loot and gold.

The upshot is this game has no plot, so there's no reason to play it for the story, and also tedious combat, so there's no reason to play it as an action game. Why play it then?

You're better off playing Dragon Age: Origin, Cyberpunk 2077, or The Witcher 3, to name a few other RPGs off the top of my head.

DOS 2 is easily one of the best RPGs I've played - ever. Great immersive gameplay and the graphics, audio, voice acting and storyline are just fantastic. It's also the only RPG I've played through more than once as the combat system is deeply intricate with so many combinations of skills. It deserves all the awards, seriously. 

It's a great game no doubt - but nothing is perfect so here's some of the bad: 
-There's really no tutorial on the deep intricacies of game mechanics and which stats to stack or not to stack. It's about experimentation and trial and error. Reading forums and game sites are almost essential to understand the plethora of play styles and tactics. It's really easy to make a ton of mistakes that are show stopping on your first play through that may even require a game restart. 

-There are complete "cheese" tactics that break the game. Some cheese only works once off while other cheeses are ongoing and affect the entire game. I don't feel cheese tactics should exist in any game because it's like lawful cheating. 

-Knowing or not knowing the "cheese" tactics can snowball into whether the game is either really difficult, moderate or really easy. Technically some aren't cheese tactics but it's just how you optimise to the game. The game has certain mechanics and hard coded attributes that make skills and abilities rather unequal. Some skills are clearly trash in almost all situations where another unassuming skill can turn out to be the best thing since sliced bread. The game clearly pushes you to certain overall techniques of play and if you don't, the game really punishes you for it. 

-Inventory management can be a lot better. It's a bit tedious at best but not a deal breaker. 

That said, the combat mechanics is one of the most intricate, immersive and combinatorial I've ever played despite certain biases the game pushes.

[h1] A Divine Fantasy RPG [/h1]

Divinity sin 2 is a fantasy RPG with a rich story and a immersive world. I Wanted to play this game, because i ran out of things to do in BG3, which made me crave for more of that kind of an experience. I Had decent expectations, but oh BOY i was blown away by this game.

You start the game as a sourcerer (not sorcerer) being transported in a ship to a place called Fort Joy, which houses others like you who have been caught by the law for using source magic. After some events, the ship happens to be attacked and sinks to the bottom of the sea dragging you with it. To your luck though, you happen to survive and make it to Fort Joy where your journey begins!

Depending on your character, you might have a completely different journey compared to another character created. The world is very reactive to your character, which means race, gender, history and reputation come into play in conversations and relationships and even fights. Your character matters in this game and makes it feel more authentic in the process

The combat is surprisingly similar to BG3's. The real difference of it is, that the game values staying still and possibly passing turns. In a vacuum it doen't sound that great, but in practise the feel of this combat is better than BG3's. Overall, the combat is very smooth, unique and a solid system that works fantastically.

Now, the way the story is told is by dialogue that is voiced, though contrary to BG3, DOS2 has no cutscenes. This doesn't matter though, because as you experience the story you tend to fill in the gaps with your imagination, like with a book. This works in the games favour and makes it so good and great to experience/read/listen.
This was one of the core reasons for me that the game felt so smooth and complete. There was never a moment, where something regarding the action during a dialogue didn't make sense, because i tended to fill in those gaps by visualizing it.
Everything was just meant to click in a way to make you feel something. I cannot explain with words, how good the story is. It is just something that has to be experienced, though not having cutscenes can absolutely be a minus, if you don't like that.

Overall, the game is in my opinion is better than BG3. I Have not experienced anything like it in a long time. Last time i really experienced true immersion, amazing story and perfection was with World Of Warcraft, which really doesn't have that anymore, so i am glad to have one of these experiences once more.

I Recommend this game 100%. If you have even a slight interest in fantasy RPG's or strategy games in general, this is your game.

Fantastic cRPG. Turn based is strictly superior to RTwP so any time a turn based cRPG gets a AAA level release it's a must play, and Larian delivers for sure. Encounters where you simply have to defeat a few chumps are few and far between and Larian really lets you stretch your creative problem solving legs to get around obstacles. This is a great game but it is TOUGH. It's got plenty of story, beautiful graphics and lots to see and explore, the lore is excellent as well. Character classes are adaptable and interesting and there are usually a few ways to do any particular problem.
BUT If you want to play any of the higher level difficulties you'll need planning, class knowledge and to be saving a lot. I recommend playing on the easier levels for at least one playthrough; I'm a veteran of DOS, POE and BG but when I came back to play this on Tactition after finishing BG3 on honour mode? Ouch. It pulls no punches and you really need to know how to build the characters optimally if you're going to have a chance. It *is* a great game, but be prepared to crunch the stats and do a lot of googling to work out how to survive the higher level difficulties.

A sprawling RPG, which, as is typical, is more about the journey than the destination. The game delivers on a premise of freedom and player choice, with the first chapter (Fort Joy) the most successful. Here there is a great sense of detail, agency and being part of a much larger story. The second chapter is also very good, but the problems start to emerge. It’s quite easy to run into fights that cannot be won, which leads to the player creeping around the map and hovering over enemies to see if they can be tackled at the current level. The final chapter is a mixed bag of unfinished ideas, and features a number of poorly explained fights that have a specific but difficult to discern solution. 

It’s abundantly clear that the game was meant to be longer but could not be finished. Eventually all is revealed and the game ends. The writing at a small scale is very good, delivered in very well executed voice-overs and as text. It’s only as you zoom out and consider how all the parts ultimately fit together that it becomes less satisfying. 

The mechanics are good, and the combat is less dependent on RNG than most games of this type, though there are, of course, elements of this. The crafting is good but there is so much of it that it’s a bit overwhelming, and the player will likely settle on a few things and ignore the rest, while lugging around tons of junk. Equipment, too, suffers from the Mass Effect 1 problem of overabundance – very slight differences and trade-offs across an ever-increasing number of stats (the gift bag feature of upgrading kit seems like a good idea). 

Overall it’s a great game, but I hope that in Baldur’s Gate 3 Larian learned to properly scope the project so that the experience is consistent from start to finish.

I'm about half-way through the campaign and I've got to say, if you are like me and came to this older CRPG from Baldur's Gate 3, this game will feel very familiar. But in a good way. The game is extremely open-ended and flexible. You are only limited by your imagination and your skill set as to accomplish the various tasks set before you. You can use violence to solve your problems by fighting everyone. You can slick talk your way through sticky situations. Or you can just turn people into chickens. If you can dream it, you can probably do it.  

Like BG3, you are dropped into a situation (you are arrested and taken to an island prison due to magic being suddenly made illegal) and from this starting point, it's all about the story you discover as you explore and interact with the world. You could get five different people to sit down and talk about their campaigns, and you would end up with five different stories.

What is my story like? Well, it's shaping up to be about a cowardly petty criminal slowly turning into a hero  out to save the world from an acorn-related disaster with the help of a talking squirrel. And some stuff about being chosen to rescue the gods from a corrupting force that's turning magic into a source of evil. 

Here are the main differences between Divinity: Original Sin 2 and BG3:

1. This might be a hot take but I much prefer DOS2's combat system. I found it much more intuitive since it was designed to be videogame-y rather than use the D&D rule book when I don't play table top RPGs. In DOS2, you get action points each turn that can you use for movement and attacks. Skills have a cooldown of a set number of turns  before they can be used again instead of a set number of uses between long rests. It's all very easy to understand so I was free to focus on tactics instead of worrying about dice rolls on things I barely understand. Best of all, it doesn't feel like attacks miss half the time. 

2. The companion characters are less of a focus. Like BG3, there are six origin characters that can serve as companions if you create a custom avatar. They are an interesting bunch, both well-written and well acted by the voice actors, and each one has a questline that spans the length of the game. However, interactions are really spartan when compared to BG3. There are only certain points in the game when they will comment on events and when you can converse with them and get more information on their backgrounds compared to the exhaustive interactions you could have in BG3. What's here is gold, but the DOS2 companions feel well... like videogame characters instead of people.

3. It's less visually polished. To be expected since this game is close to a decade old. It's a still a good looking game to be sure but don't expect impeccably mo-capped character models or triple A quality cut-scenes. Everything stays within the birds-eye view of the isometric game world at all time so you aren't going to get close ups of the onscreen action. 

I seriously hope that the developers' next game can take the battle system of DOS2 and meld that with the visuals and character writting of BG3 to make a combination that's the best of both worlds.

Relative to the first game, which is to say when you consider the difference in technology, narrative and experience that Larian Studios had available at the time of both DOS 1 and DOS2, it is dramatically less impressive. However, DOS 2 is still a masterpiece in its own right. The only real faults with the game are evident only in relation to the first game and expectations of the game-play that one might have from the experience of DOS 1. DOS 2 is much longer than the first, but with much less finely tuned pacing that makes the game feel like a slog especially in certain sections. There are too many narrative arcs that feel like the exposition is just being thrown at you. Actual agency in terms of the way quests play out feels limited despite the game's implications otherwise. And finally, the combat -contrary to all of its bells and whistles - leaves a lot less room for tactical innovation over just having ideal skills and stats.

On it's own the game shines. It is a whopper of a story - even with all the parts in which it drags - and it presents a universe of characters as compelling as any Genre Fiction novel. Fights are extremely entertaining and do present many opportunities for meaningful and intentional exploitation of game mechanics. It may not be the most enthralling experience for a genuine RPG master, but it does give a lesser player the illusion of being one. It's much easier to put down and come back to later - without suffering RPG amnesia - than most in the genre and the story has many self-contained bits that feels rewarding as you trudge toward completion. 

Personally, it's not the kind of RPG that has significant replayability but even without trying to 100% one can easily squeeze out 100-200 hours of playtime. I am extremely cheap when it comes to purchasing video games, but it is one that I think is absolutely worth the money.

Off the tail of [i][b]321 hours[/b] in Baldur’s Gate 3[/i], I decided to pick up the entire Divinity collection since the bundle was on sale for 60% off. As its immediate predecessor (in terms of Larian’s published works at least) it still manages to be worse in just about every way. 

I’ve sunk half a days worth of time into it at this point and feel like I’ve done hardly anything. The story feels sluggishly generic, practically beat for beat with games like Baldur’s Gate 3 and Pillars of Eternity II: Deadfire (as far as Act I anyway, since I [b]just[/b] got out of the main starting area) and is drip-fed outside of books scattered around. If you’ve ever played Skyrim, imagine you potentially didn’t get to use your Shouts [u]at all[/u] [i]before[/i] getting the Horn of Jurgen Windcaller. That’s what I’m dealing with right now.

Speaking of books, while some give recipes or skills upon reading them, there’s no way to give the latter to any character except the one who read it, and no way to know which ones will grant anything beforehand.

Autosaves are abysmal in their consistency so you get sent back an hour when you most need one, usually getting one right after you get back to where you were, and there’s no indication of when you should quicksave unless you have shift held down to see enemy sight cones. I finished a fight and thought I was safe after having just unlocked a waypoint, only to have my entire party killed in one hit before I could react.

There’s no way to confirm skill points being used prior to spending them; attack cones aren’t ever accurate in who or what they actually hit; characters sometimes can’t attack due to being unable to see if they stop in the same spot before a fight (most often when one is triggered right after you pass through an entranceway); and loot is totally randomized outside of Unique items so on top of not being able to get your loot back after dying prematurely following a fight, combat becomes less about tactics and more about putting all your points into your attack attributes and ganking one enemy at a time hoping the rest keep targeting your tank. Instead of being fun or exciting it just becomes a hindrance in these circumstances. This includes shops too.

There’s no setting to have your avatar automatically selected after a fight so you’ll end up speaking to a character that you’ve saved or otherwise as a random member of your party, which most often has the same dialogue lines aside from whatever tags your character has (i.e. Undead, Elf, Scholar, Jester, Noble), and you can’t view your companions attitudes towards you despite there being a tutorial explaining how to do so. 
They never really interact with you after the prologue area anyway besides a quick line before a required fight or a quip to themself while walking. You can talk to them, sure, but they’re just combat vessels following you around otherwise. They’re characters that are written with potential, but having to go out of your way to see that except when you first meet them makes the party dynamic nonexistent for me, especially when most of your time with the game is going to be spent [i]in combat[/i] or traveling between fights.

There are also select community mods built-in that are available to you in the form of “Gift Bag Features” which don’t warn you that they disable achievements prior to enabling them. This is especially worrisome considering the majority are QOL enhancements, and from what I’ve heard some cause more difficulty than they seek to fix.

It has the humor of the other games but completely lacks their charm. I should note that I decided to skip the first D:OS after Beyond started refusing to let me launch it on my second day of playing no matter what I tried, making me have to restart my computer every time, and Divinity II felt disjointed and uninspired compared to the original 2 (yet I guess I didn’t exactly get a lot of experience with them either).

In a word, I wouldn’t even call D:OS2 [i]clunky[/i], it’s just [i][u]muddled[/u][/i].
I’m very excited to see Larian’s abilities moving forward following the astounding Baldur’s Gate 3, but [i]this[/i]… isn’t in the same boat.

Lohse from Divinity: Original Sin 2: The Best Waifu
Lohse from Divinity: Original Sin 2 stands out as a beloved character, capturing the hearts of players with her rich backstory, compelling personality, and unique abilities. As a talented musician and gifted performer, Lohse’s charm is immediately apparent. However, it is her inner struggle and resilience that truly define her as the best waifu.

At the heart of Lohse’s character is her battle with an internal demonic presence. This ongoing conflict adds layers of depth to her persona, making her more than just a typical RPG companion. Her bravery in facing this darkness, and her determination to maintain her sense of self, resonate deeply with players, showcasing her strength and vulnerability.

Lohse’s personality is another key factor in her appeal. She is witty, compassionate, and fiercely loyal, making her a memorable and endearing companion. Her interactions are often laced with humor and warmth, providing a refreshing contrast to the darker themes of the game. This blend of lightheartedness and depth makes her a multifaceted character who feels genuinely alive.

In terms of gameplay, Lohse is a versatile asset. Her abilities as an Enchanter allow her to heal and support the party, while also wielding powerful offensive spells. This versatility makes her invaluable in combat, reinforcing her role as a dependable and capable ally.

Ultimately, Lohse’s combination of a compelling backstory, engaging personality, and gameplay versatility make her the best waifu in Divinity: Original Sin 2. Her character arc is a testament to resilience and the power of inner strength, qualities that resonate profoundly with players, ensuring her place as a beloved figure in the gaming community. in summary, gaym is good and lohse gib me big boner (idk about the guy inside of her but i'll let it slide JUST this ONE time)

Divinity: Original Sin 2 is a top-down RPG and turn-based combat game.

THE GOOD:
- *Much* better than the original D:OS! This game is actually quite fun! It's like an early version of Baldur's Gate 3, set in a totally different world.
- Has the concept of a limited set of Origin Characters to choose from as playable characters, which allows the game writers to better tie your character into the story. Each Origin Character has their own special quest and unique conversation options.
- Epic plot that is full of surprises (if you don't mind that your major enemies always arrive everywhere before you do).
- Combat is varied and detailed enough to keep it interesting.
- Supports online multiplayer and local two-player coop via split-screen (this requires controllers)!

THE BAD:
- When I was introduced to the characters at the beginning of the game, they all seemed to be awful people (they all proved to be sympathetic enough that they grew on me over the course of the story, though).
- While the game is playable via controller, the controls are a bit awkward and the camera angles are never good.
- You sometimes need to do fast precision clicking, but that's next to impossible with a controller. There is no option to go turn-based outside of combat.
- Certain puzzles and parts of the game can be quite obscure and frustrating. It's nothing you can't solve with good old Web searching, but trying to read the designer's mind is never fun.
- The plot is fairly linear.
- I think the writers flubbed the ending a bit. The structure of the ending is in two parts: (1) a single choice you make at the very end, and (2) a mosaic of the consequences of all the little choices you made during the story. I usually find a mosaic ending to be best for story RPGs, but in this case all the mosaic consequences follow directly from the single choice you make at the very end. So at the end it doesn't feel like your little choices during the story actually amounted to much.

THE UGLY:
- There were plenty of minor plot or conversation glitches, but nothing game-breaking or terrible.
- We experienced a few crashes.
- I hope you aren't afraid of the sight of blood.

يجب عليّ أولاً أن أوضح أنني لم ألعب الجزء السابق من Divinity: Original Sin برغم أنني سمعت الكثير من المديح عنه، لكني للأسف لم أجد وقتاً له. ولذلك كنت سعيداً بإصدار الجزء الثاني، لأنني وأخيراً وجدت فرصتي لدخول هذا العالم لأرى بنفسي إن كان يستحق سمعته فعلاً. وبهذا دعوني أبدأ المراجعة.

القصة:
تدور القصة حول مجموعة من الشخصيات ذات قدرات خارقة تسعى للهروب من الأسر واكتشاف أسرار قوة الألوهية. كل شخصية لديها خلفية فريدة وأهداف خاصة، مما يضفي عمقًا إضافيًا على القصة. لكن، بعض الأحيان، قد تشعر أن الأحداث تتباطأ بسبب تداخل القصص الجانبية وكثرة الحوارات، وهذا قد يؤثر على اندماجك مع القصة.

نظام القتال:
نظام القتال في اللعبة يعتمد على التكتيك والاستراتيجية. يمكنك استخدام البيئة المحيطة لصالحك واستغلال العناصر المختلفة مثل النار والماء والسم لتحقيق الأفضلية. لكن اللعبة لا تكافئ ولائك واستمرارك مع سلاح واحد، وهذه سلبية مزعجة برأيي. القتال بعيد المدى قد يكون غير موزون، بل يمكن أن يكون مكسوراً نوعاً ما إذا كنت تعرف ما تفعله، مما يجعل بعض المعارك سهلة بشكل غير منطقي.

التصميم البصري والصوتي:
اللعبة تقدم رسوميات جميلة ومفصلة، من تصميم الشخصيات إلى البيئات المحيطة. الموسيقى والمؤثرات الصوتية تعزز من الجو العام للعبة وتساهم في خلق تجربة غامرة. الموسيقى المصاحبة للمعارك تزيد من حماسك وتشعرك بأهمية كل خطوة تقوم بها.

العالم المفتوح:
العالم المفتوح في اللعبة مذهل ومليء بالتفاصيل. يمكن أن تشعر بالإغراق في حجم العالم وأنشطته المتعددة في البداية، لكن بعد فترة، قد تبدأ بملاحظة التكرار في تصميم الأماكن والأنشطة، مما يمكن أن يقلل من جاذبية اللعبة مع مرور الوقت. تصميم بعض الأماكن، مثل مراكز الأبحاث، يتكرر بشكل ممل وهذا يقلل من متعة الاستكشاف.

عناصر تقمص الأدوار:
عناصر تقمص الأدوار تتضمن الدروع والملابس ذات القدرات المختلفة. يمكنك التنويع بينها، لكن بمرور الوقت قد تجد أن التأثيرات غير ملحوظة بما يكفي لتستحق استثمار الوقت والموارد فيها. بعض اللاعبين قد يشعرون بأن اللعبة لم تعطيهم محفزًا كافيًا للاهتمام بهذه العناصر.

التحديات التقنية:
من ناحية التقنية، اللعبة تعمل بشكل جيد مع بعض المشاكل التقنية البسيطة مثل الحشرات البرمجية أو مشاكل الأداء على بعض الأجهزة. لم أواجه أي مشاكل كاسرة للعبة أو ضياع للحفظ، مما يجعل التجربة مقبولة بشكل عام من الناحية التقنية. لكني سمعت عن بعض اللاعبين الذين واجهوا مشاكل تقنية كثيرة لدرجة أنهم توقفوا عن اللعب.

التقييم النهائي:
"ألوهية الخطيئة الأصلية الجزء الثاني" تُعتبر تحفة فنية في عالم ألعاب تقمص الأدوار. القصة الغنية، الشخصيات المتنوعة، ونظام القتال العميق يجعل من هذه اللعبة تجربة ممتعة ومرضية للغاية. رغم بعض الصعوبات التي قد يواجهها اللاعبون الجدد وبعض المشكلات التقنية البسيطة، تظل اللعبة خيارًا ممتازًا لمحبي هذا النوع من الألعاب.

التقييم النهائي: 9.5/10

هذه اللعبة تستحق بالتأكيد التجربة لمحبي ألعاب تقمص الأدوار، وتعتبر واحدة من الأفضل في هذا النوع من الألعاب.

Negative since it can be a very frustrating game. The way some things are structured you quite easily lose a few hours.

Random dialogue options/ characters = INSTA-DEATH (like i have to explore everything to gain enough XP. to add random insta death characters all over the place to make me lose a few hours is annoying.

Sometimes the dialogue options are all kinda bad or at least bland in the choices. Hard to choose anything if you have nothing you actually can agree with.

The accents really don't fit the game. Personally really disliked them. 

You can randomly lose companions. sometimes permanently. Worst part is they will keep all the gear they had in the inventory. (SPOILER. when you enter the well of ascension. if you just walk through the door instead of talking to all your characters first you lose them?? sure they got the icon that there is dialogue but all game that hasnt meant anything important. you also lose companions through other fairly random events if your not hardcore trying to follow the story but even then you cant know the first time..)

One of the most frustrating things about this game. Some checkpoints overwrite your own saves.. Like im not joking. itll start a boss fight and overwrite your last quicksave. If its your first time playing it will very likely end your game right there.. or make you go back several hours (SPOILER you wake up some ancient witch.. and at the start of the fight it overwrites the save. fight starts with a big aoe and your surrounded by wolves so unless you played it before you will likely lose)

The whole concept of only being able to do certain quests in a certain order. it is annoying. i have to spend ages looking for a quest my level when ive already explored the map 3 times. not to mention there are several maps. it can take the fun out

Overall you almost have to read guides in order to not meet any nasty surprises thanks to the bad design. It is fun and there is a lot of ways you can fight and all.. but a good game shouldn't be plagued by so many little problems. And looking at the company. and the game that came out afterwards (baldurs gate) and it being practically the same system.. so i really dont feel bad giving them a bad review.

I was told this was the best game to play after Baldur's Gate 3, and as I get to the end that was totally right. It fully feels like a stepping stone to get to BG3 and is also just fantastic to play. 

Pros:
- Honestly having so many levels feels very satisfying even compared to BG3 where you only got 12
-The fighting is just really fun. Took a second for me to get used to the small changes (like turn limits, source, and no resting needed for spells), but it was certainly well done and had so many possible moves/spells.
- Characters are great (Sebillle ily), and a fun plot that I enjoying playing out
- Voice acting is very good (Sebille VA ily)
- There's so many options for armour that all have different ways to boost you, so many different designs, ability combinations, sets to match etc. (not being able to level it up is a little unfortunate, but I think it makes sense for the game so I wouldn't say that's a con)
- Making your party specialize in different areas and have different abilities is so fun (which realtes heavily to the fighting, but in general it's just great)
- the support abilities are so much better here than BG3 - partially because I didn't need to worry about wasting a spell slot, and because some only took 1 slot which would be all i was left with, but also they were just legitimately better

Different than BG3 (not really pros or cons, just differences when comparing a relatively older game to a modern masterpiece):
- The characters (side characters and main ones) don't have nearly as much depth in this game even though what we get from them is great
- no cutscenes (again, these points aren't giving any negative points in my eyes, just stuff that could make it even better if it came out now)
- Levelling up doesn't come with as much customization and changes
- Aspects of the story (and side characters) are both a bit more convoluted and simple, as well as just harder to follow - still good
- There's no long resting, and short resting (using bedroll) is only for restoring health. Honestly besides missing the camp that aspect was actually more convenient
- Oh yeah there's no camp clothes, and costumization options due to no cutscenes, but there's also more armours and lacking informal clothes doesn't do anything
- there's no dice rolling which I missed even though it was kinda nice that I didn't have to worry about rolling a 1 lol
- Moving and actions are counted in the same 4 moves (the amount you can walk per move depends on character) which I can see being better or worse. I like both

Cons:
- The levelling system can be a little annoying and I ended up needing to look at level maps which I guess is elaborated on in my next point
- The game doesn't feel like it guides you enough or gives you quite enough freedom (to be clear this is a grievance, but isn't nearly as bad as that makes it sound, just something I encountered a couple times). There were times I would accidentally stumble into enemies who were too high levelled, but they were already aggravated (or I couldn't talk my way out) so I would have to load before I met them and just avoid them until I could reach the correct level. There was also one major time that I didn't know I had to trigger events in a specific order (or a couple times I thought something would trigger another event so I avoided it only for it to not matter - like going on that kids boat in act 1) and what I needed to do wasn't really said which led to me kinda fucking up a part of the main story... Also led to me not getting resolution on Peeper and reloading continuously to save him for half of Arx only to realize he had no relevance after the arc he got introduced in and I had just not casted Spirit vision where I was supposed to
- The persuasion (or I guess this applies to tags and just general interactions too) aspect can be annoying, maxing it for the main character is the move, but it can still be annoying just because occasionally your allies will be the ones to be spoken to, especially after battles if you aren't the closest one to the NPC. Then you have no persuasion and are lacking your tags which can lead to another issue. Also had to reload a couple times to bring my MC closest to the NPC before a fight ended or to intentionally trigger conversations that my allies accidentally did

Anyway I'm sure there's many more things I could add (and I probably should've waited until I actually finished, I'm sure the end is great) especially to the pros, but if you enjoyed BG3 and see this review, yes it's a fantastic game to play after BG3. It's got no major issues, and is just great, if you're craving another game like BG3 (or just craving any game to put some hours into) this is the one

I am going to run out of superlatives for Larian developed games soon.

Surely Baldur's Gate III will blow my mind.

DoSII for those of you who have played the first original sin game this is very much a game which has added onto an already great formula in an excellent way. I really like the addition of the origin characters allowing you to play a roll within the game world. Less a go anywhere do anything kind of RPG more a play this character in an excellently fleshed out game world.

If you haven't played a Larian game yet DoSII might be the best place to start. However be warned the game does not hold your hand if you do not know the mechanics it can be a real struggle at the start. As I found in DoSI

I will try to keep the review pretty spoiler free so here are my general thoughts

Pros
You can skip the loading splash screen (Larian know how to show me a good time)
You can exit to windows from the pause menu. (Larian really know how to show me a good time)
Save anywhere. You can even scum save during combat. this is really great I am fed up with developers ruining single player games by trying to balance them. There should be zero balance in a single player game imnho. If you paid for the game you should be able to cheese it to your heart's content.
Turn based combat. There is no frustrating RTS micro management in the game.
The range of skills is increased from the original game and this is a really good thing. There are so many combos and effects you can use. You can really keep the game fresh by varying your combat.
There is still many ways to cheese the game if you care to or if you are stuck on a tricky fight. I think this is a really important in single player games.
Excellent well fleshed out characters with full voice acting.
A compelling narrative and deep game world with some intriguing lore ripe for immersion.
Fixed level enemies mean some fights you cannot win without levelling up. This is great imo and makes all those side quests worth while.

Cons
The ending and final battle was pretty unremarkable. Which is I suppose is at least consistent with the first game. I got there and felt "is that it?". After nearly 100 hours of greatness this left me wanting a little more.
Again in keeping with the first game I felt the opportunities for "Role Playing" were limited. Maybe this is because I picked and origin character (Fane) and therefore felt a little railroaded into his story.
The game seemed pretty easy to me. I played on classic difficulty and maybe I had learned from original sin 1 about the usefulness of summons. But to me the game was much easier than the first title.
The music to my taste was standard bland fantasy RPG fare. It wasn't bad but often a superlative score can lift a game from merely average to stupendous. The DOSII score was not that.
I barely used a potion in the entire game. I managed without buffs and mostly without healing which may be down to my difficulty choice but I did feel I was carrying around lots and lots of junk.

Overall one of the best RPGs I have ever played. By no means perfect (what game is)  but still a long way ahead of the competition.

9/10

Divinity: Original Sin 2 is an absolute triumph in the world of RPGs. From its stunning visuals to its deep, immersive gameplay, every aspect of this game is crafted with meticulous attention to detail.

One of the standout features is the sheer depth of choice. From character creation to dialogue options, the game allows for unparalleled freedom in shaping your own path. Want to be a noble hero, a cunning rogue, or a powerful mage? The choice is yours, and each choice alters the course of your adventure in profound ways.

Combat is another highlight, blending strategic depth with dynamic, turn-based action. The ability to combine spells and abilities with environmental effects leads to endlessly satisfying tactical encounters. Whether you're coordinating with allies or exploiting enemy weaknesses, every battle is a thrilling test of skill and strategy.

Beyond its gameplay, Divinity: Original Sin 2 boasts a world brimming with personality and charm. From bustling cities to eerie dungeons, every location feels alive and teeming with secrets waiting to be uncovered. The attention to detail in both visuals and sound design further enhances the immersive experience, drawing you deeper into its fantastical world.

Moreover, the game's cooperative multiplayer mode is a stroke of genius, allowing you to team up with friends to tackle challenges together or even betray each other in pursuit of your own goals. The flexibility and replayability offered by this mode are a testament to the game's commitment to player choice and agency.

I bought this game during steam sales, seeing good reviews i decided to give it a shot. 
At first i wasn't convinced, but after a little time i started to really enjoy it. Now that i finished it, i can say without the shadow of a doubt that this has been one of the greatest games i've played for the past 20 years. And i play a LOT. Trully an amazing, immersive experience.
The story is great, the combat is great, the (many) little details are awesome, the build customization is great, going from character creation (with racial skills/passives) to choosing a specialization (mage, rogue etc), then a spec in the spec (fire mage ? earth mage ? necromancer ?...), then secondary spec etc, its re-playable thanks to this aspect of the game and the fact that you can ultimately change what happens in game with choices of dialogue leading to different endings.
The only thing i didn't quite enjoy as much for now is the crafting aspect and consumables (potions, grenades, scrolls), but its my fault since i'm kind of a meta dog, i tend to go with what seems like the most OP things. No doubt that you can actually make good use of it and actually do a run based on it.
In the same way, some passive talents can lead to interesting results if you dare to try them.
Finally, i love the graphics and the animations, but i really have to take my hat off to the guy who did the soundtracks, while all of them are good and add to immersion, some of them are straight up masterclass.

Nothing i disliked really, except the fact maybe that sometimes you can "accidentally" kill someone and it can be an issue lore-wise or for completionists. Not game breaker in any way though, and easily avoidable with a quicksave.
I've seen some people complaining about bugs, they might be fixed with definitive edition because in 300 hours i didn't get any.

Basically if you like RPGs, don't even think about it, you have to try this game.
An absolute masterpiece with a soundtrack that outshines probably anything i've listened to. One of the best experiences i've ever had playing a video game.

One of the greatest RPGs ever made. The level of strategy in combat and the absolutely compelling character interactions are the highlights imo. Being a big fan of Bioware (RIP) RPGs I found a lot to love in this title. If you're a fan of these types of games just get it, you won't regret it.

New to DND style games and decided to play this with a few friends. And as a new player to this genre of game, for new players, I say this is a skip. The game has a lot of fumbles with it. You would think that when playing a DND type game that you are going to create your own character, class, etc and you can do that. But you are only going to get away with that if you play on the most basic difficulty because the enemies are weak and as a first time player you are not going to know where to allocate your points into what stats.

So me and my friends played on the standard normal difficulty and things led to many things that break the so called immersion of this game. Save scumming because we did not like certain quests ending the way they did, dying because the enemies take away your armor in one hit, not positioning properly for a fight you didn't even know was about to break out and get AOE to death, and persuasion checks that are pointless if you succeed them, you're still going to fight. So that adventure got canned and never finished.

So then I did a solo run, still can't play the way I want to, so I default to what everyone does, look up builds. Now I am not playing a game the way I want to play, I am playing just to beat it and the builds work. Now we go even deeper issues with this game. Enemies, your class skills need to be properly tuned and fixed with a patch. I don't care how old this game is, enemies being blocked by a house door or being behind furniture or something in the house and they have line of sight to attack me, but then I try to shoot them with my ranger no line of sight. Enemies clipping terrain, now you can't crowd control and knock them down to negate some damage. For the people that like to be immersed in these type of games, how can you be when 90% of the NPC's are rude as **** forcing you to become not the hero but just someone that gets things done with so much blood on your hands. NPC's you helped in the past act like they've never seen you or saw you help them in the past and sometimes see you have something of their's "Give it to me! Or your life." You want another example. "You helped me and I've given you my thanks, now p*** off." That doesn't seem like immersion to me, that just makes everything in the game look like XP numbers to me now.
I know this is concidered outdated old game, but this is certainly worth a play. BG3 came from this stock. So it HAS to be good. and YES! it is worth your time.

The difference between BG3 and D:OS2 can be explained pretty easily if you've ever looked at all the stuff that 5e has done to make D&D more simple and accessible-- all of that makes for a worse video game. D:OS2 is dense in systems, but it takes the time to teach them to you and by the time you get going, you really feel like a god of some sort. Combat is never about chipping away health, every turn has important decisions that can be made that affect how the combat rolls out, with enough dynamism to allow both you and the enemy to bounce back into contention from the brink of death at almost any point in the fight. Also, the music is better.

The quest writing and characters of BG3 are certainly more mature and more polished, but OS2 feels like I am sitting down with a bunch of friends back when I was a kid to make up a story on the spot. BG3 is the best version of 5e D&D as it actually exists, but OS2 is the game you thought you were playing when you first learned what Dungeons and Dragons was. Both are good, but damn I love OS2.

D:OS2 has better combat than Baldur's Gate 3. I wish they could have kept the action point system and elemental combination system...but then it wouldn't be a D&D game, I guess.

For me it is not a CRPG. It is much more a quest/puzzle game. Unfortunately there are enormous amount of situations where you just try solve a puzzle like in 90th. Looking through very inconvenient small interface for very small point to click. A lot of battles implies new rules. It is not a question of studying moves of enemies but new rules constantly. It is not fair from gamepoint. You can may ideal moves throughout the game and constantly face situation where some mechanics do not work, some new condition appears and you loose. Just because you must do something absolutely different after reload. And it is not logic and using tips. Just new rules for new battle. 
It is still a RPG which is my favorite genre, and there are a lot of very good ideas. But for me Larian just has not managed to cope with those realisation (and I doubt the someone would succeed with them). There just too many thing that do not work properly. If compare with Pillars of Eternity 2 this game much more bold and sometimes can bring you joy and satisfaction (and even more than in POE2) but at the same time half of the game is just pain and dissapointment with a lot of negative emotions.

ANother dissapointment is the presence of the "golden route" to approach each act. SO de jure it is semi-open world, but de-facto you must approach each act in linear way to minimize negative feelings (like spending 2 hours to win a boss battle being significantly underleveled to receive no reward at all or being unable to proceed further because you have not acquired some story ability yet). 

And the last point - you do not believe in this world as there are too many simplifications and gamedesign elements which are not properly explained. At the beginning of the game magisters are low level enemies with low heals and armour, with the same magisters are megatanks in the end. No. I do not believe in this! In other games enemies are more dangerous with increased levels but here they just have more healts and armour. And your damage is just bigger. No. It is a bullshit from the story and lore perspective.

Play BG1-2, POE 1-2 (no Pathfinder - it disrespects your time much more), if you want CRPG.

The way the dialogue is written for your character is unlike many other RPGs I've played, written in 2nd person in such a way that you only get the broad strokes of what your character is saying.

Playing an Origin character, the Red Prince, had mixed results for me. I picked him because the general consensus is custom characters feel a bit lacking in comparison. But it was plainly obvious I was playing him far nicer than the writers intended him to be, because every one of his unique dialogue options ran contrary to how I intended to play him. I think this level of choice could actually be a detriment, i'd rather Larian have done something closer to Deus Ex where the Origin characters at least had more spoken dialogue and didn't give you 4 dialogue options every time for a response, where most of those result in the sameish reply from the NPCs. It's just fluff at that point. BG3 has this issue too but to a lesser extent.

The gameplay was... too messy. Larian struggles to make a UI that doesn't feel user-hostile and messy as hell to use. BG3 after this managed to get to what I consider passable - DOS2's is just not enjoyable to interact with and requires constant micromanaging to keep usable, and that's time spent away from interacting with the core gameplay and the story. DOS2's turn-based combat feels slow and clunky compared to similar games, and the surface system would have benefitted immensely from using a grid. Animations are slow and lack weight, prepare to hear "I'll yield to none!" quite a bit, and be forced to often choose between moving and attacking since they draw from the same resource of action points. 

The leveling system is a bit too freeform for my tastes. There's no classes per se, simply tons of skills you can choose form an level up in, but to me it is nice to have the structure of a class but the option to branch into others via multiclassing or the like. This felt like utter choice paralysis for me as the game doesn't do a particularly great job easing you into its mechanics either. At some point it started feeling like I needed to pull up the wiki and build guides just to operate at a base level.

Gear progression is tied to the merchant's randomized inventories and did NOT feel like it kept up with enemy levels unless you were grinding out every single quest in an area, which didn't feel good. By the time I reached the end of Act 1, the challenge felt reasonable for the Act boss, but as soon as Act 2 began I felt miles behind the level curve once again and put down the game because I wasn't down to spend more than 28 hours in Act 1 again. 

It's a shame though because I was enjoying the story, as grim and dark as it was from the outset. The art style is nice, though the presentation is extremely basic when it comes to dialogue unfortunately. I was interested in the world Larian had crafted and the Lizards, as lazily named as they are, were my favorite race playing as the Red Prince. 

I gave it a good shot but this game isn't for me, it just never clicked, but there's something good here that you might be able to enjoy better than me depending on your tastes. The game also is free of nickle-and-dimeing predatory microtransactions, so I'd sooner recommend it than a lot of triple-A titles right now.

Uh... this IS the best RPG I've played. I've played A LOT of them. Over 1000 since 1986. 

Both Divinity I and II are better than Balder's Gate 3 and I put 440+ hours into that.  

The Only let-down in DOS2 is the lack of crafting, it had the system and all the bits in place but doesn't get utilised like it does in DSO1 - but this game is extraordinary fun, and has an amazing set of features.  I won't spoil it for you but I cannot recommend this game enough. Besides being truly beautiful, imaginative, tactical terrain, a rich variety of enemies and friends, excellent dialogue (inc very funny parts) the Shops/Traders stay meaningful - even when groaning with gold you can always find something worth splurging on; < this is SUCH a rarity in most RPG games. The acting and voice-overs are top-notch. The combat system is wonderful fun with a staggering variety of options for play styles, though it can be punishing with the wrong team or wrong skills, you can get opportunities to re-skill at any point through the definitive extras. The game rewards you for hunting high and low and looking in random places - a beautiful trait for the born explorer that makes you want to search every corner. The range of quests are exceptional, never boring, the music, visuals, and optional game settings are so nice and the creativity in the landscapes is so enjoyable to explore. There are puzzles, tricky bits but a robust online help community if you get stuck. This game offers so many ways to play inc. all kinds of boosts and checkboxes so it doesn't drag you down trying to complete sections with the wrong characters, and lets you change up. This allows you to be more leisurely and OP if you want to be and just smash your way through the map, valuing your time.  I've only just arrived in Act 3 - and I already wish there was a divinity III (or IV) or DLC, or just more, more, more of it. Just excellent - bravo Larian!

After playing Baldur's Gate 3 (BG3), I decided to explore the Divinity series, starting with Divinity: Original Sin 2 (DOS2). Content-wise, DOS2 is significantly larger than both Divinity: Original Sin (DOS1) and BG3.

POSITIVES:
-Content Size: DOS2 offers an expansive world and more content compared to its predecessor, DOS1, and BG3.
-Improvements: Many of the critiques I had for DOS2 have been addressed and improved upon in BG3.

CRITIQUES:
- Companion Interactions: I started my playthrough on Tactician mode. In BG3 and DOS1, companions often comment on battles, adding a lively and immersive element to the game. However, this interactive dialogue is almost absent in DOS2, which diminishes the sense of companionship and immersion.
- Storytelling: The storytelling in DOS2 is primarily conveyed through text. While the narrative is still good, it doesn't quite compare to BG3, which utilizes animations to enhance the storytelling experience.

OVERALL, while DOS2 is an EXCELLENT game with a lot to offer, especially in terms of content, it falls short in certain areas where BG3 excels, particularly in companion interactions and animated storytelling.

[h1]🧙 Divinity: Original Sin 2 - The Epic RPG You Didn’t Know You Needed 🧙[/h1]

Step into the mystical world of [b]Divinity: Original Sin 2[/b], where your choices matter, your enemies are ruthless, and your allies might just stab you in the back (literally). Get ready for a wild ride filled with magic, mystery, and mayhem. ⚔️✨

[h2]🌍 A World Like No Other 🌍[/h2]

Welcome to Rivellon, a vibrant and dangerous world where every corner hides a secret, and every decision could be your last. With its beautifully crafted landscapes and richly detailed environments, [b]Divinity: Original Sin 2[/b] will have you exploring every nook and cranny, sometimes just to see what’s lurking in the shadows. 🌲🏰

[h2]👥 Choose Your Companions Wisely 👥[/h2]

In [b]Divinity: Original Sin 2[/b], who you travel with can be just as important as your own skills. From the charming but deadly rogue Ifan to the enigmatic undead Fane, each companion has a story to tell—and a unique way to kill you if you’re not careful. Choose your friends wisely, or end up with a dagger in your back during a critical battle. 🔪💀

[h2]🎲 Turn-Based Combat: Strategy Meets Chaos 🎲[/h2]

Love chess? Love fireballs? [b]Divinity: Original Sin 2[/b] combines strategic turn-based combat with chaotic magical warfare. Position your characters, exploit the environment, and use a plethora of skills to outwit your enemies. Or, you know, accidentally set your whole party on fire. It happens. 🔥🧙‍♂️

[h2]🛠️ Crafting and Customization: Be the Hero (or Villain) You Want to Be 🛠️[/h2]

Why be a regular hero when you can be an undead elf who talks to animals and sneaks around in a barrel? The customization options in [b]Divinity: Original Sin 2[/b] are as deep as they are hilarious. Craft your gear, choose your skills, and decide if you want to be a noble knight or a sneaky thief—or something else entirely. 🏹⚒️

[h2]🔮 Choices Matter: Your Story, Your Way 🔮[/h2]

Every decision you make in [b]Divinity: Original Sin 2[/b] can alter the course of your adventure. Will you save the helpless villager or sacrifice them for greater power? Will you ally with a mysterious cult or expose their dark secrets? Your choices shape the world, the story, and your companions’ fates. Choose wisely, because Rivellon remembers. 🌟🔗

[h2]😅 The Good, The Bad, and The Hilarious 😅[/h2]

[b]Divinity: Original Sin 2[/b] isn’t just epic; it’s also packed with humor. From unexpected conversations with animals to bizarrely funny outcomes of your decisions, the game never takes itself too seriously. However, be prepared for a steep learning curve and complex mechanics that might make your head spin faster than a polymorphed chicken. 🐔🌀

[h2]🎤 Final Thoughts: A Masterpiece of Magic and Mayhem 🎤[/h2]

[b]Divinity: Original Sin 2[/b] is a masterclass in RPG design, offering a world that is as deep as it is wide, with characters and stories that will stick with you long after you’ve saved (or destroyed) Rivellon. Whether you’re a veteran adventurer or new to the genre, this game offers something for everyone—just don’t forget to quicksave often. Trust me. 🛡️✨

So grab your wand, sharpen your sword, and gather your party. [b]Divinity: Original Sin 2[/b] is waiting for you to carve your legend in its world. Happy adventuring! 🌍🧙‍♀️

Before i even start talking about the game, here's a little tip that could save some players a headache. If you experience frequent crashes and have the Razer Synapse installed, unlink the game in the software parameters. It completely fixed the issue for me.

So, after playing to and loving BG3, i've become curious of Larian's previous works. I've heard people saying that BG3 should have been called DOS3 and i can perfectly understand their point, because they have A LOT in common. In both games, you start as a prisoner on a ship that crashes and are saved by a mysterious voice. There are a lot of little examples like this where the two stories are quite close. Some BG3 companions are directly inspired, or a mix from two DOS2 companions (i see Astarion as a mix between Sebille and the Red Prince).

But the resemblance doesn't stop there. Both games have no real huge travels between maps, they include 3 or 4 big zones absolutely packed with content, the last one being a city. So yeah, they're pretty alike (excepted BG3 has of course a lot more bells and whistles, like cinematic scenes for more or less every NPC encounter, there are none here). That hasn't been a problem for me as i found both games to be excellent, but at times i felt like they haven't been  very subtle in the way  they copied stuff from DOS2 to make BG3.

This being said, DOS2 might be inferior from a technical perspective but there are some aspects of the game that are better. DOS2 is tougher. I played both in tactician difficulty and i found DOS to be much more of a challenge. I'm now at the beginning of the final act and there have been times where i wondered if i would be able to go on  (you can't lower difficulty after picking tactician), because some fights are really tough and requires that you make the best use of the topography and of your skills. Not saying that BG3 is an easy game, but winning in DOS felt more rewarding to me.

There are also a ton of items. It seriously felt like i was playing a looter shooter at times. This is due to the fact that  there is a skill that gives you a chance from getting a magical item from basically any container in the game. Even better, a part of the loot is random. It adds an element of surprise and i prefer that to fixed loot tables. You can really finetune your gear to make exactly the character you want.

If you're looking for something to play after BG3, DOS2 can definitely scratch that itch, if a more modest technical presentation isn't an issue for you. If you can get it for 12 or 13 bucks during a sale like i did, it's a complete steal.
