Divinity: Original Sin 2 was on my list of games to try and I almost went with Baldur's Gate 3 instead of this game. BUT I am so so glad I didn't DOS2 is probably in my top 3 of best games I've ever had the pleasure of playing. This was a jam-packed adventure of great stories, sharp twists and turns in the plot, and super interesting mechanics. I easily put 100 hours into my first play-through of the game and I don't regret a second of it. 

PRO's 
- Deep story telling, and inter-connecting quests
- Deep character ability customization (want to be an electrifying fire wizard who summons monsters?)
- The variety and amount of different options you have for any situation you encounter is fantastic
- Endless hours of playtime per play-through, there is so much you can do!

CON's
-The game is a little wonky sometimes with what it allows you to do and where
- Combat for the first probably 15 hours of the game feels like you are a deer in the headlights
- Quest locations are a little iffy, you get a general "area" to look in rather than exact locations. (Points of Interest)
- If you don't use thievery on at least one character you are nerfing yourself in my opinion 

Overall I can't say I made the wrong decision buying this game over Baldurs Gate 3. Larion Studios I salute you, love you, and hope you make more Divinity games as I can't recommend this one enough :D

END THOUGHTS/TLDR- ||BUY THIS GAME|| if you like CRPGS

I have "played" this game for hours now, and while the visuals and story are pretty incredible, I would not recommend based on two factors: The lack of ability to configure WASD character movement for keyboard, and the lack of interactive tutorials.  
I find the native point-and-click movement really uncomfortable.  It feels like I have less mobility than I should. I know that there exists an option to use a PC controller, but I prefer not to, as most (if not all of my) PC games support WASD movement so I see no reason to use a controller for just this one game.  I tried to get used to it but found myself taking a break from the game and coming back, then habitually trying to use WASD and getting annoyed that it does not work.
The in-game "tutorial" is just an instruction manual and not really a tutorial at all.  For instance, there was a tutorial page that simply says something to the effect of: add all skill points to your tabs to become stronger! That's it? Really? I had to sift through all of the many menus to figure out what tabs this is referring to. Before I knew it, I was thrust into combat, not knowing a thing about how the combat system works.  I would have preferred a more interactive combat trainer that shows me how to use my abilities, how to move, and little nuanced things that a non-DnD player like me should know (such as how drinking a potion when my character is undead actually deals damage somehow?)
Overall the game seems to be great quality, and based on the other reviews I've read it has some incredible content.  However, I do not like that I'm more than 4 hours into the game and still have no idea how to play it. I'm tired of investing time trying to learn the game and find whatever appeal that other reviewers found.  So far I've just been asking myself "When does this get fun?" I'm glad others enjoy it, but this game is definitely not for me.

For context:
I just finished the definitive eddition with three friends and it was a real drag.
It requires a surprising amount of disciplin to stick close to each other and experience content together, expecially because there is a lot of reading and inventory management to do, so you will have to constantly wait on each other to get anything done if you dont want anyone to miss out.
I personally gave up on actively caring and following the story half way through act two.
The game is full of situation you have to know are comming before hand if you want to have any shot at surviving them. So it usually boils down to: Knowledge-check -> die horribly-> reload previous save -> repeat
This is partly due to the encounters having a fixed level, meaning you can stumble into an ambush that is three levels above you with people directly spawning into the backline of your team. It also doesnt help that a lot of story encounters are scripted so that certain enemies always go first.
All in all this lead to a mostly frustrating gameplay experience on my end, and had me sit in safety and wait for others to trigger combat in the last act.
On top of all of that, there were a bunch of bugs and glitches further draining my patience and causing a bunch of additional reloads. 
Anyone who wants to play it alone or with just one other friend and does not mind loading safes a lot might get their fair share of fun out of this.
For me it was 50% frustration 30% whining over bugs and the finicky controlls and camera angle 20% actual enjoyment of the game.

But that is just my experience, you do you ;D

I really love this game. It's a staple of RPG video games, in my opinion. The character's are well thought out and diverse in personality. The combat system is easy enough to manage; just make sure that you're constantly doing side quests for bonus XP. Otherwise, the game is much harder. I only have one game with more playtime than this one, and that's because it's so amazing. There are a few bits that are clunky, though. For example: in Fort Joy, to progress further you need either a shovel or a character who is a lizard. Finding a lizard is easy enough: the Red Prince. However, if you've already assembled your party, or you don't want to recruit the Red Prince, that means you have to find a shovel, and there aren't many of those around. I had to look up where to find one.

Overall, I'd say that this game is better than not. I'd recommend it to anyone who has played games like the Baldur's Gate series, or any other topdown RPG. It's just beautiful. Also, the computer has a weird glitch: I have played 64 hours at the time I'm posting this. IDK why it shows 24.

It's a good RPG game with a lot of focus on tactical turn based combat. It's RPG system is unique. It has it's own classes with their own strengths and abilities, you can even specialize in multiple classes and make your own. The enemies are challenging, especially on tactician, forcing you to think through every turn and plan for every encounter. The environment is very interactable during battles and plays a huge role on you'll be fighting. The combat system is one of it's biggest strength.

The only complain I'd have is that enemies in tactician are so difficult that normally you can't win without cheesing the combat to some degree. This breaks the immersion a bit and makes you feel like you've been cheating the entire time. Although one could argue that it's not cheesing and it's just tactical decision making using the game's systems. Personally, it mostly feels like cheesing.

The story and quest is alright, nothing too deep. Mainly just heroes trying to save the world from some evil force or calamity.

It's a really good game. It's just not for me personally. I think depending on tastes, some people will like it and others will find it boring. At the time of writing this review, I played it on tactician difficulty and got bored and stopped after getting to Arx which is about 60-70% through the game. I could however see myself returning to the game in the future maybe on classic difficulty.

I'm still gonna give it a positive review because it deserves it.

Possible one of the best games I've ever played (haven't played Baldurs Gate 3 yet). 

I just finished my first play through on Classic Mode and one of the biggest issues I had with this game is that it felt too hard at the time. Could very well have been down to a skill issue as I did a lot of research on character builds near the end of my play through and ended up having to adjust all of my characters and get a lot more skills and put different weaponry on every character. With that being said, every big fight seemed nearly impossible to win from the start of the game. The game should be difficult but I felt it was impossible to kill all of the enemies without doing cheese strats like leading enemies into NPCs that will help but like I said I guess I didn't have great builds for my characters. 

I would like to get all of the achievements but I don't think I will be able to beat this game in honour mode at all. I saved the game like every 2 minutes.

Overall, a very great game with lots of game-play mechanics that allow for creativity and lots of play-styles. Even though I'm not a creative person myself, researching the game allowed me to see videos where people are doing the most crazy stuff to kill enemies. The number of skills that cab be used and the amount of skills that I've never seen in any other game surprises me and I expect to see that uniqueness in Baldurs Gate 3.

Short version: A very detailed and well-done Tactical RPG that has oodles of replay value.
Pros
+Massive character customization : 4 Races and an Undead version of each one, class-less build style (archers and melee fighters can all wield "magic" if you invest skill points to an Element)
+Story line with impactful decisions : people you meet and interact with in Act 1 can make appearances or mentions in Act 4
+Adjustable difficulty that adapts : Enemies don't just get increased stats as you climb in difficulty. Some get additional buffs or auras that completely flip the script of a fight.
+Turn-based combat
+Music is pretty decent
Cons
-Humour can be hit-or-miss : Some of the story leans into a light-hearted side that just doesn't work sometimes. And item tooltips are also very punny.
-Some fights can feel completely overwhelming or "cheesy" (enemies stun-locking you with water and electricity, for example)
-While replay value is very high due to multiple characters with backstories to explore, the very beginning feels bogged down or sluggish on a 2nd + playthrough (imo before you get a "jump" skill)
Uncertain / Opinion
-No "New Game +" : All the consumables and items you find on one playthrough are lost on a new game. There is no bringing stuff from the previous runthrough into a new game. This promotes a "smoke em if you got em" style of play, but I'm more of a hoarder nature.
Conclusion: 100% recommend - the sheer customization available and replay value of this game is staggering, and well worth the price.

D:OS II is a fantastic game. If you enjoy the likes of Diablo, Baldur's Gate III, or - like me - have a deep-rooted love of all things D&D you can skip the rest. Just buy it. 

I've sunk a lot of hours into this game in a short amount of time (Steam says 18, it's really more like 80 - the counter reset several times) and it's seriously excellent. Just the prologue took me over 12 hours and I didn't even attempt a completionist run. Even so, it didn't feel like 12 hours as the story sucked me in HARD.

One of the main reasons I've played D:OS II so much is the Deck. It runs fantastically on the deck, and controller support is excellent, unlike it's younger sibling BG III whose nested wheels drove me mad and relegated the game to a mouse and keyboard. The scheme is simple and works well with a controller, so much so that most of my time in this game have been via a docked steamdeck with an xbox Elite 2 controller. It's flawless. 

This game can be a real challenge, forcing you to embrace the boundless depths of RPG customization to best suit your play style. Quick saves are a life saver (pun intended) as approaching an encounter even a little bit wrong or unprepared can end in sudden disaster. Use them, and use them well. 

My only complaint about this title is the RNG feels a bit unbalanced at times, but perhaps that's just me. 

Overall, 10/10 will play for MANY more hours.
